editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TRYALS AND CONDEMNATION OF LIONEL ANDERSON, alias Mun≈øon, WILLIAM RUSSEL, alias Napper, CHARLES PARRIS, alias Parry, HENRY STARKEY, JAMES CORKER, And WILLIAM MARSHAL, FOR HIGH TREASON, AS Romi≈øh Prie≈øts, Upon the Statute of 27. Eliz. Cap. 2. Together with the Tryal of ALEXANDER LUMSDEN a Scotchman, AND The Arraignment of DAVID JOSEPH KEMISH for the ≈øame Offence. At the Se≈ø≈øions of Oyer and Terminer in the Old-Baily, on Saturday January 17th. 1679.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Collins and John Starkey Book-Sellers in Fleet-Street near Temple-Bar, 1680.

div.head: THE TRYALS, &c.
div.opener: On Saturday the 17th of January, 1679. at the Se≈ø≈øions-Hou≈øe in the Old-Bayley, by Vertue of His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øion of Oyer and Terminer and Goal-delivery of Newgate, for the County of Middle≈øex and City of London, the Per≈øons hereafter named were Arraigned and Tryed. And after the u≈øual Proclamation for Attendance was made, the Court proceeded in this manner:

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Crown.
sp.p: KEeper, ≈øet David Jo≈øeph Kemi≈øh to the Bar, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: David Jo≈øeph Kemi≈øh,
sp.p: Hold up thy Hand, (which he did.)

Thou ≈øtande≈øt Indicted by the Name of David Jo≈øeph Kemi≈øh of the Pari≈øh of St. Giles's in the Fields, in the County of Middle≈øex, Clerk, for that thou being born within the Dominions of our Soveraign Lord the King, and being a Prie≈øt, made and ordained by authority derived from the See of Rome, after the Fea≈øt of the Nativity of St. John Bapti≈øt, in the fir≈øt Year of the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, and before the 15th of November, in the thirtieth year of the Reign of our Soveraign Lord the King that now is, the Laws and Statutes of this Kingdom of England not regarding, nor the Penalties in the ≈øame contained any ways fearing, the ≈øaid 15th day of November, in the thirtieth year of the King afore≈øaid, at the Pari≈øh of St. Giles's in the Fields, in the County of Middle≈øex afore≈øaid, traiterou≈øly, and as a fal≈øe Traytor of our Soveraign Lord the King, thou wa≈øt and did≈øt remain and abide again≈øt the Form of the Statute in this Ca≈øe made and provided, and again≈øt the Peace of our Soveraign Lord the King his Crown and Dignity. How ≈øaye≈øt thou, David Jo≈øeph Kemi≈øh, Art thou Guilty of this High Trea≈øon whereof thou ≈øtande≈øt Indicted, or not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Kemi≈øh.
sp.p: Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Cr.
sp.p: Culprit, How wilt thou be Tryed?

sp.speaker: Kemi≈øh.
sp.p: By God and my Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: God ≈øend thee a good deliverance.

sp.speaker: Kemi≈øh.
sp.p: I cannot ≈øpeak, I am not able to ≈øtand upon my Legs a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What does he ≈øay?

sp.speaker: Capt. Richard≈øon.
sp.p: He ≈øays he is ≈øo ill and weak he is not able to ≈øtand.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then he mu≈øt have a Stool.

sp.speaker: Kemi≈øh.
sp.p: I am not able to ≈øpeak in my own defence, and I have had no time to prepare my ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Captain, He ≈øhall ≈øpeak ≈øoftly to you; and you ≈øhall report it to the Court again.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richard≈øon.
sp.p: You may ≈øpeak ≈øoftly to me, and I will give an account what you ≈øay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How will he be Tryed? ask him.

sp.speaker: Kemi≈øh.
sp.p: I would de≈øire my Tryal might be deferr'd till I be in a condition to An≈øwer for my ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: 'Tis, I think, very fit, if your Lord≈øhips plea≈øe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: He mu≈øt Plead fir≈øt. Have you recorded his Plea?

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis recorded.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why then look you Captain Richard≈øon, you mu≈øt take him back, the Court does think fit, and Mr. Attorney does think fit, by rea≈øon of his extraordinary ‚Ä¢ nfirmity, that it is not ≈øea≈øonable to Try him now. And that the World may not ≈øay we are grown Barbarous and Inhumane, we are all contented he ≈øhould be ≈øet by. Therefore let him be returned back, and in the mean time you mu≈øt take care that he have that rea≈øonable looking to as is fit for a man in his condition to have.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: Acquaint him with what the Court ≈øays to you.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richard≈øon.
sp.p: I will, my Lord.

sp.speaker: M. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I de≈øire that the Judges may declare their Opinion in it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: They have done ≈øo already, we do all con≈øent to it. Therefore take him, and go get him a bed.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Cr.
sp.p: Set William Ru≈ø≈øel, alias Napper, to the Bar. Who was Arraigned upon an Indictment of the ≈øame form, only the day of the Fact differing, which was laid to be the 27th of November, in 30 Car. 2. To which he likewi≈øe pleaded, Not Guilty, and put him≈øelf upon the Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Cr.
sp.p: Set Henry Starkey to the Bar. Who≈øe Indictment was the ≈øame, only the Time differing, which was the 26th of January, 30 Car. 2. And he al≈øo pleaded, Not Guilty, and put him≈øelf upon the Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Cr.
sp.p: Set William Mar≈øhal to the Bar. Who being Arraigned upon a like Indictment, and the time mentioned to be the 15th of January, 30 Car. 2. And being asked, Whether Guilty, or not Guilty, an≈øwered thus:

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhal.
sp.p: My Lord, I do find by this Indictment, that I am Arraigned for the ≈øame Crime for which I was tryed before: I do humbly de≈øire to know, Whether, according to Law, I can be tryed twice for the ≈øame Fact?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: No, according to the Law you cannot be tryed twice for the ≈øame Fact, nor are you; for before you were Indicted for having an hand in the great Con≈øpiracy, for being a Con≈øpirator in the Plot, and now you are Tryed for being a Prie≈øt, and abiding in England.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I was tryed before your Lord≈øhip as a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: You were ≈øo.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Now I am tryed for a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: Which is another Trea≈øon.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: If I am tryed for a Prie≈øt, I conceive I cannot be tryed unle≈øs as a Criminal Prie≈øt: and I conceive I cannot be tryed as a Criminal Prie≈øt, unle≈øs it be as a Prie≈øt that hath had ≈øome attempt or de≈øign again≈øt the Government.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: Nay, you mi≈øtake there; There may be Prie≈øts that have had no hand in the Plot; if you were acquitted for the Plot, yet you remain a Prie≈øt ≈øtill. Do you ≈øuppo≈øe then that every Prie≈øt had a hand in the Plot?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly conceive, that Prie≈øthood as Prie≈øthood is no Crime at all.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: That is no Crime at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: Come, You mu≈øt plead without more a do: and you mu≈øt not u≈øe any more Speeches.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: You mu≈øt be governed in all things by the direction of the Court.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I do ≈øubmit to the direction of this Honourable Bench; but, my Lord, give me leave to ≈øay, I ≈øuppo≈øe I am indicted upon 27. Eliz. Now if it be made appear, that according to that Statute Prie≈øthood alone is not Trea≈øon‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: Then you mu≈øt ≈øpeak it afterwards, but now you mu≈øt plead.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: But if it be at lea≈øt made doubtful, then it becomes a matter of Law, and I have ju≈øt occa≈øion to in≈øi≈øt upon it, and pray Coun≈øel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt Dolben.
sp.p: You mu≈øt plead to the Indictment fir≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Why can I ask Coun≈øel after Plea pleaded?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: Yes, you may if matter of Law ari≈øe: and you may have Coun≈øel as to that matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: The Court is of Coun≈øel for you in ≈øuch a ca≈øe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Baron.
sp.p: But you mu≈øt plead fir≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: You cannot be heard at all till you have pleaded to the Indictment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray take the directions of the Court.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I have a great deal of rea≈øon to ≈øubmit to this Honourable Court, that hath been ≈øo full of Mercy and Clemency, and therefore I do an≈øwer, That I am not guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: How wilt thou be tryed?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: By the King and my Countrey.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, that will not do.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: By God and my Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: God ≈øend thee good deliverance. Set Alexander Lumsden to the Bar. Who≈øe Indictment being of the ≈øame nature, only reciting the Fact to be 11. Maii 31. Car. 2di. he pleaded, Not Guilty, and put him≈øelf upon the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set James Corker to the Bar; who was al≈øo Arraigned for the ≈øame Trea≈øon done upon the 24. Octobr. 30. Car. 2di. and being asked, whether Guilty or not Guilty, an≈øwered in the≈øe words.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly beg the Judgment of the Court; I humbly conceive, my Lord, I have been already tryed and acquitted for this Crime.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, that hath been over-ruled already in the ca≈øe of Mar≈øhall ju≈øt now, who is in the ≈øame Condition; You are not now tryed for the ≈øame fact for which you were tryed before.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: My Lord, I ≈øuppo≈øe there is ≈øomething particular in my ca≈øe: I was expre≈øly indicted as Clerk, one that received Orders from the See of Rome.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: His Addition was Clerk, that is all.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you were not charged in that Indictment for this Fact.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: My Lord, I pleaded to that Indictment, under that Qualification of Clerk.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So men do when they ≈øay in the Indictment, Labourer, plead to it in that qualification, but if a man plead by the name of Gent. the Que≈øtion is not whether he be a Gent. or no, but whether he be Guilty of the Fact he is indicted for; and the Que≈øtion in your ca≈øe was not whether you were Clerk or were not Clerk, but whether you had a hand in the Plot or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: If the Jury had found you a Prie≈øt at that time, it had been a void finding more than they were to inquire of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: He was told ≈øo at that time he was not tryed for a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Ellis.
sp.p: After you have Pleaded, then you may urge what you have to ≈øay.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: Then I ≈øay, I am not Guilty. And he put him≈øelf upon the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set Lionel Ander≈øon, alias Mun≈øon to the Bar. Who≈øe Indictment was for being a Prie≈øt, and abiding here the 28 Jan. 30 Car. 2. And he pleaded not Guilty, and put him≈øelf upon his Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set Charles Parris alias Parry to the Bar, who≈øe Indictment was of the ≈øame Nature, for abiding here 30 Maij. 31 Car. 2. And he al≈øo pleaded Not Guilty, and put him≈øelf upon the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set all the Pri≈øoners to the Bar that are to be Tryed. William Ru≈ø≈øel, Henry Starkey, William Mar≈øhall, Alexander Lumsden, James Corker, Lionel Ander≈øon, and Charles Parry.

sp.speaker: Captain Richard≈øon.
sp.p: They are all on.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: My Lord, I have been Confined, I have not had my Liberty till within the≈øe two or three days.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: I have not had my Friends to come to me, to advi≈øe me upon what account I was to be Tryed.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richard≈øon.
sp.p: He ≈øays, he wanted his Friends to advi≈øe for what he was to be Tryed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, he knows he is to be Tryed for a Popi≈øh Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richard≈øon.
sp.p: Here is one ≈øays he is ≈øick.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Capt. Richard≈øon.
sp.p: 'Tis Ander≈øon.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton.
sp.p: Then he mu≈øt have a Chair to ≈øit down on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Wee'l Try him fir≈øt that is ≈øick.

div.p: Then the Pri≈øoners were called to their Challenges, and the Jury of Middle≈øex appearing upon their Summons, and none of them being excepted again≈øt, the Twelve that were fir≈øt called and Sworn, were the Gentlemen after named.
Then they were numbred, and Proclamation for Information in u≈øual manner was made.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Come, begin with the Sick-man Ander≈øon; and ≈øet away the re≈øt.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Lionel Ander≈øon, hold up thy hand. You that are Sworn look upon the Pri≈øoner, and hearken to his Cau≈øe. He ≈øtands Indicted by the name of Lionel Ander≈øon, &c. Upon this Indictment he hath been Arraigned, and thereunto hath pleaded, Not Guilty; and for his Tryal hath put him≈øelf upon God and his Countrey, which Country you are. Your Charge is to enquire, whether he be Guilty, &c.

div.p: Then Roger Belwood E≈øq; of Council for the King in this Cau≈øe, opened the Indictment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p:
May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury. The Pri≈øoner at the Bar, Lionel Ander≈øon, alias Mun≈øon, ≈øtands Indicted for High Trea≈øon, and it is alledged in the Indictment, That he being born within the Kings Dominions, and made a Prie≈øt, and having received Orders by pretended Authority, from the See of Rome, he did the 28th. day of January
la≈øt come into the Kingdom of England, that is, as 'tis laid, in the Pari≈øh of St. Giles in the Fields in this County; and there he did abide contrary to the Form of the Statute. And this is laid to be Traiterou≈øly done. To this he hath pleaded Not Guilty, and we are to prove it upon him by the Kings Evidence, whom we are now to call.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, for my ≈øtaying in the Kingdom, I had the Kings expre≈øs Command, and an Order from the Council-Board in the year 71.) They Ordered Mr. Peter Wel≈øh, and my ≈øelf, and ≈øome more to ≈øtay, for Writing again≈øt the Temporal Power of the Pope, for the Power of the King of England again≈øt the Court of Rome. After this Plot was Di≈øcovered, I came to the King, being afraid of being involved in the general Calamity. So I came to the King, and ≈øaid, Sir, I de≈øire to know what I may do.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do, Why?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Good my Lord hear me out. My Lord Privy Seal brought me an Order from the Council Board, and ≈øo 'tis Recorded, and I think Dr. Oates will be ≈øo ju≈øt to me, as to acknowledge that he hath ≈øeen it, and this is all that I have to ≈øay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you have an Order from the Council to protect you, you mu≈øt apply your ≈øelf el≈øewhere; our bu≈øine≈øs is to try the ≈øingle i≈ø≈øue, whether you have offended again≈øt the Law.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, I that am but a poor ≈øingle Individuum, who am born with an innate and implicit Obedience to my King, judge whether it lies in my power to di≈øpute with him and his Council, whether they can do this or no, or that I mu≈øt obey the Kings Command.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: This is not a time for him now to in≈øi≈øt on this matter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Re≈øerve your ≈øelf till the Kings Coun≈øel have done, and the Evidence given.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: Let him ≈øave his Speech till ≈øuch time as he comes to an≈øwer for him≈øelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Give him a Chair, if he be not able to ≈øtand.

div.p: Then Sir John Keiling, one of the Kings Learned Coun≈øel in the Law, pur≈øued the Charge thus,

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p:
May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip and you Gentlemen of the Jury, Lionel Ander≈øon otherwi≈øe Mun≈øon the Pri≈øoner at the Bar, ≈øtands indicted here, for that he being a Subject Born within the Dominions of the King, hath taken Orders from the See of Rome, and hath contrary to the Law come into England, and ≈øtayed here as a Traytor; for this Trea≈øon he is indicted, and the Indictment is grounded upon the Statute of the 27th. Eliz. a Statute made almo≈øt a hundred years ≈øince, and it was upon great occa≈øion; for it tells you plainly, That the≈øe Prie≈øts that had taken Orders from the See of Rome, were not only bu≈øie in ≈øeducing and perverting the Kings Subjects to the Romi≈øh Super≈øtition, but they had made many attempts upon the Government, rai≈øing Sedition and, Rebellion and levying of War again≈øt their Soveraign,
which is evident from the Preamble of the Statute it ≈øelf. And it is true, the lenity and mildne≈øs of our Princes hath in a great mea≈øure let this Statute lye a≈øleep: they have not been willing to execute the ≈øeverity of the Law upon all occa≈øions at all times; but the occa≈øion being renewed at this time, for the remedying of which, this Statute was principally made, (that is to ≈øay, rai≈øing Seditions, and Commotions, and Rebellion again≈øt the King, the particulars of which I ≈øhall not inlarge upon it hath been notorious in this place) that is the rea≈øon of the pre≈øent pro≈øecution of the≈øe Per≈øons. Who have not been contented to enjoy the indulgence of our Princes, (which hath been extended to them, notwith≈øtanding all their former numerous affronts that they have given) but have rais'd new Commotions, and made attempts upon the Per≈øon of our King, and of our Government, and that is the occa≈øion upon which the≈øe Per≈øons come to be Tryed. It is not purely (tho' that is a main ingredient) that they are tryed quatenus Prie≈øts, but as Ordained by the See of Rome, and coming into England and abiding here. For a Prie≈øt, if he be Ordained by the See of Rome, if he comes not here, can do no hurt; but it is his coming and abiding here, that makes him the Subject of this Puni≈øhment, and hath occa≈øioned this mans Pro≈øecution. Now my Lord, we ≈øhall prove that this Ander≈øon alias Mun≈øon hath taken Orders from the See of Rome, who≈øe authority con≈øtituted him a Prie≈øt, and this we ≈øhall prove by ≈øeveral in≈øtances and ≈øteps; and then we doubt not but you will take that care for the pre≈øervation of the Government, and for the Peace and Quiet of the Nation, which becomes you, and give a Verdict according as your Evidence ≈øhall lead you.

div.p: Then Sir George Strode, the Kings Serjeant at Law, managed the Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Strode.
sp.p: My Lord, we ≈øhall call our Evidence. The Fact is this, That this Per≈øon being a Subject of the Kings, and having received Orders from the See of Rome, that is, being a Romi≈øh Prie≈øt, did come and abide here contrary to the Statute; not that his Prie≈øthood is the Crime, no tis his being a Subject of the Kings, and owning an Authority from abroad, and thereby denying the Authority of his own Soveraign. To prove this, we ≈øhall call Dr. Oates, Mr. Bedlow, Mr. Dangerfield, and Mr. Prance, (who were all Sworn.) Set up Mr. Dangerfield fir≈øt. Mr. Dangerfield, tell my Lord and the Jury what you know of the Pri≈øoner at the Bar, Mr. Ander≈øon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: What I do know again≈øt him?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, for being a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: What, that particularly?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, that particularly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p:
My Lord, about the latter end of May, or beginning of June, when I was a Pri≈øoner for Debt in the Kings-Bench, this per≈øon took occa≈øion to ≈øpeak privately to me, and de≈øired me to go into his Room: he told me he had received a Letter from my Lady Powis, and that Letter was burnt. But the next Letter that
came from my Lady Powis, he would ≈øhew it me. And he did ≈øo; and the Contents of the Letter was, as near as I can remember, ju≈øt thus: Sir, You mu≈øt de≈øire Willoughby to ≈øcour his Kettle; which was, to Confe≈øs and receive the Sacrament, to be true to the Cau≈øe. A little after, that was Saturday, and I think it was the next day, being Sunday, I went into Mr. Ander≈øons, ali√†s Mun≈øon's Chamber, and there I went to Confe≈ø≈øion, and received Ab≈øolution. And he ≈øent me to another per≈øon to receive the Sacrament, who was ≈øaying Ma≈øs at that time. And when I had received the Sacrament and returned to him again, he did tell me, That he, as a Prie≈øt, did give me free toleration to go and be drunk, and drink with one Stroude; and I asked him, being ≈øomething ≈øcrupulous in the matter, Whether I might lawfully do it, having but ju≈øt received the Sacrament? he told me, Yes, he gave me authority ≈øo to do, being for the good of the Cau≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you a Papi≈øt then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: You went to Confe≈ø≈øion to him, and received Ab≈øolution?

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: What was the good of the Cau≈øe that he meant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: If you plea≈øe, give an account of the whole thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: That was, as I was employed in a general Affair for the Catholicks: for I was to u≈øe my endeavour to bring over Stroud to be a Witne≈øs for the Lords in the Tower, concerning the Plot, and to invalidate Mr. Bedloe's Te≈øtimony.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Here I am upon my Life and Death; all the World knows me, that hath heard of my Name‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Pray make no Speeches, if you will ask any Que≈øtions you may.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: No, I wont. I wi≈øh that all the Puni≈øhment of Hell and Damnation may come upon me, if I ever opened my mouth to this Rogue for one Farthing, or about any bu≈øine≈øs in the World.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You mu≈øt not call him Rogue in open Court. Let us have that re≈øpect ≈øhewn us that is fitting, and ≈øo ≈øhall you have, but this Language we mu≈øt not ≈øuffer.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: In the fir≈øt place, I will bring all the Pri≈øoners in the Kings-Bench Pri≈øon to te≈øtifie, That I de≈øired to be removed to Newgate, for here was the greate≈øt Rogue come in that was in England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: This mu≈øt not be ≈øuffered.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you will ask him any Que≈øtions, you may.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Well, come Mr. Dangerfield, in the fir≈øt place, Who ever ≈øaw you with me? 'Tis impo≈ø≈øible but ≈øome body mu≈øt ≈øee you with me, if we were together, as you ≈øay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: My Lord, there is one Hill, that is now a Pri≈øoner in the Kings-Bench, that ≈øaw me ≈øeveral times go into his Chamber.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was there any body by when you confe≈øs'd your ≈øelf to him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: Confe≈ø≈øions u≈øe to be in ≈øecret.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: No, my Lord, he was not in the Chamber, neither was it rea≈øonable he ≈øhould, but he ≈øaw me go in often.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Surely, Mr. Dangerfield, you and I could not be ≈øo well acquainted, but ≈øomebody or other mu≈øt take notice, that we ≈øpoke together ≈øometimes. Now if you can produce any one body that will te≈øtifie it, I will be bound to be hang'd, and ≈øay no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: He is not bound to bring Witne≈ø≈øes to this purpo≈øe. He ≈øwears the Fact charged upon you po≈øitively.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: This Hill, my Lord, that is in the Kings-Bench, hath made Oath of it before Mr. Ju≈øtice Fo≈øter.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: But, my Lord, this one thing I have to ≈øay again≈øt this man. There is a Statute made ≈øince the King's mo≈øt happy Re≈øtauration, enumerating Trea≈øons, which ≈øays, That all Trea≈øons ≈øhall be as in that Act: And further adds, That none ≈øhall be Convicted of Trea≈øon, but by two lawful and credible Witne≈ø≈øes. Now the wi≈ødom of our Legi≈ølators, having an Eye to future Safety and pa≈øt Practices, does provide, That no one ≈øhall ≈øuffer as a Traytor, but one that is by good and credible te≈øtimony convicted of Trea≈øon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray ≈øpeak out, Sir, for I cannot hear you.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, I under≈øtand the meaning applicable to me thus, That ≈øince the Statute does u≈øe the word (Credible) as well as Legal, it does judge that both would be very nece≈ø≈øary. Now that he is not a credible Witne≈øs I can prove‚Äî

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why is he not credible? certainly if he be legal he is credible.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: No, my Lord, that does not follow. Fir≈øt the‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: 'Tis not his time to make this ≈øort of defence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: He ≈øhould have done it before the Witne≈øs was ≈øworn, if he would except again≈øt his Te≈øtimony.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But why is he not a good Witne≈øs, pray?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, a man pilloried twice, that hath broke Pri≈øon once, and committed other hainous offences‚Äî

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is the Record of any of this?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, I'le tell you how I prove it. That worthy Gentleman, Col. Man≈øel, whom this Villain would have involved in‚Äî

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You mu≈øt not do thus, abu≈øe per≈øons with words without proof.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: He mu≈øt not be ≈øuffered ≈øo to do.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, I will do ≈øo no more, indulge a little to my innocency and infirmity.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You don't ≈øeem to have ≈øo much infirmity upon you.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Col. Man≈øel, when this Gentleman was the Kings Evidence, as he is now, brought in the Record of this Gentlemans being pilloried, and the Council did not think fit to commit Col. Man≈øel, but committed him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you that Record here?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I have not.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: We pray we may go on then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: Set up Dr. Oates. Dr. Oates, will you tell what you know of this matter.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he is a Prie≈øt. I can in ≈øincerity ≈øay it. I have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs my ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, I acknowledge I did it. But my Lord I will ≈øhew you. Ma≈øs is no proof of a Prie≈øt: for fir≈øt the Statute makes a di≈øtinction of Prie≈øts‚Äî

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: He does execute the Office of a Prie≈øt; for I have been at Confe≈ø≈øion with him as a Prie≈øt, and have ≈øeen him Con≈øecrate the Sacrament, and I have ≈øeen his Letters of Orders as a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he wear the Habit of a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, at Ma≈øs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, are you ≈øure you ≈øaw his Orders as a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he ≈øhew you the Letters of his Orders?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, he did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Of what Order is he?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: A Dominican-Fryer he is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can you ≈øay to that?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I can ≈øay enough; but what can I ≈øay again≈øt the King's Evidence? Your Lord≈øhip ≈øees this makes a very fine Jingle, but there is no proof of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We can go no further than the Evidence. He ≈øays, You are a Dominican-Fryer: That he heard you ≈øay Ma≈øs: That he ≈øaw you Con≈øecrate the Sacrament. And I am ≈øure you allow none but a Prie≈øt to do that.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I under≈øtand by the Laws of England, that I am tryed upon a Statute which makes Prie≈øthood a Crime. Now I will ask Mr. Oates a Que≈øtion: Mr. Oates, Can you prove, That I received Orders from the See of Rome? You are to prove by this Statute three things again≈øt me. I am tryed upon a Penal Statute, which ought to be con≈øtrued mo≈øt in favour of the Pri≈øoner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton,
sp.p: Ask him any Que≈øtions, if you will, but this is not your time for arguing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, we mu≈øt do with you as we have done with others, and will do with the re≈øt. If you mean that this Statute ≈øhould never have any Effect, that is, that the Prie≈øts ≈øhall not be convicted as ≈øuch, unle≈øs we can produce Witne≈ø≈øes, that ≈øaw them take Orders, then you have avoided all the Statute; but if ≈øo be it be plainly proved, That you have done the Acts of a Prie≈øt, tho≈øe that none are allow'd of to do, or undertake to do, but a Prie≈øt, is not this a ≈øatisfaction, and a plain one too, to your ≈øelf and all the World, that this I≈ø≈øue, whether you are a Prie≈øt, or not a Prie≈øt, is well proved in the Affirmative.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I ≈øaw his Letters of Orders.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, I would ≈øpeak a little to what you ≈øay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p:
Look you, Sir, you mu≈øt not have ≈øuch liberty
as this granted to you. You may, if you will, ask Que≈øtions, but it is not your time to di≈øpute.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: You mu≈øt not invert the Order of Tryals. When a Witne≈øs is called, he mu≈øt give his Evidence. If you will ask him any Que≈øtions you may do it. But if you will ob≈øerve any thing, you have time to do it when the Kings Witne≈ø≈øes are all heard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: Dr. Oates, the Pri≈øoner did not under≈øtand ≈øure what you ≈øaid. Did not he confe≈øs to you he had Orders from Rome.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, he did confe≈øs ≈øo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You confe≈ø≈øed it your ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, how comes it to pa≈øs, that I did not come here in a Yellow Coat, and was not arraigned for a Fool? If I am a Prie≈øt, that I ≈øhould tell him I was ≈øuch an one.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, I can't tell, becau≈øe you did not put it on. If you would ask him any Que≈øtions, do.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Yes, Whether you do know me to be an Engli≈øhman? And whether you ≈øaw me take Orders from the See of Rome?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: You ≈øaid you were an Engli≈øhman, and a Gentleman, and the ≈øon of an Engli≈øh Gentleman.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you deny you are an Engli≈øhman?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
L. C. J.
sp.p: Me-thinks you ≈øpeak very like an Engli≈øhman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: My Lord, we call now Mr. Bedloe. You know the Que≈øtion, what it is Sir, concerning the Pri≈øoners being a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: He is a Prie≈øt, and an Engli≈øhman, if his Mother was hone≈øt, and he hone≈øtly born; for he is Mr. Ander≈øons ≈øon of Oxford≈øhire, as I was told.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But what ≈øay you to him, as to his being a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ever receive the Sacrament from him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: Never. But I have ≈øeen him Admini≈øter the Sacrament, and he was in a Prie≈øts habit.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I think it was at the Venetian Re≈øidents; I am ≈øure it was at ≈øome of the Emba≈ø≈øadors Hou≈øes.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: This matter is ≈øo unlikely, I know not what to ≈øay to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Que≈øtions?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Upon my Salvation I never ≈øaw him before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: It is a ≈øtrange thing, that you ≈øhould take upon you to ≈øay upon your Salvation you never ≈øaw him. How many might come into a Room, and you not ≈øee them while you are at Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He might ≈øee you, tho' you did not ≈øee him. He might come in, and you not ≈øee him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: Is that any argument, or any thing to the purpo≈øe, or does that contradict the Evidence? Does the Mini≈øter, or ought he to know all his Congregation while≈øt he is in Preaching?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I never ≈øaw him, I ≈øay. My Lord, I'le give you but one Argument, which is called Argumentum Congruentiae.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Que≈øtions?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: To what purpo≈øe will it be for me to ask him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: When he was fir≈øt taken I was not ≈øtirring, but while I was making ready, they told me, There was one ≈øu≈øpected to be a Prie≈øt. I heard him ≈øpeak in the next Room, and I knew his voice, and ≈øaid, That is Mr. Ander≈øon. I pre≈øently knew his tongue before I ≈øaw him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You knew him very well then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I never had any great conver≈øe with the man: when he was taken, they asked me, If I knew any thing of this man about the Plot? I told them, No; but he was in Orders from the Church of Rome: for I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs at ≈øuch a place. He told me, ≈øaid he, I have been in Orders, but I revok'd them, and turned Prote≈øtant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Set up Mr. Prance. Pray, Sir, tell what you know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: My Lord, I have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs ≈øeveral times at Wild-hou≈øe, and he hath given the Sacrament there, and I have ≈øeen him take Confe≈ø≈øions‚Äî

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Several times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you know him very well?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I never ≈øaw him in my life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But he hath ≈øeen you.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, I will bring Witne≈ø≈øes to prove, That I never did ≈øay Ma≈øs at Wild-hou≈øe, nor went to the Chappel: I was an Excommunicated man, for writing for the King's Temporal Power again≈øt the Pope.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long have you known him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Seven Years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often have you ≈øeen him ≈øay Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: A dozen times.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: It may ≈øeem ≈øtrange that I ≈øhould have the impudence to deny what this worthy Gentleman ≈øays. Mr. Prance dare you ≈øay you know me?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, were you never there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: Well, well, will you ask him any Que≈øtions?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Who did I give the Sacrament to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: A whole Rail-full hath been at the Sacrament at a time, ≈øeveral people I have ≈øeen receive it from him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he deliver the Sacrament to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: No, he did not, I commonly received at Somer≈øet-Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: We have done, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: The Kings Coun≈øel have done with their Evidence, and now you may ≈øay what you will.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, may I ≈øpeak now?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, you may.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, all the World knows me, and I am known to mo≈øt of the Dignified Clergy in England: My Lord Bi≈øhop of London, and Dr. Lloyd, and the Bi≈øhop of Durham ≈øent to me to tell me, that if they knew of my Tryal they would be here. My Lord, I have lain under an ill Cen≈øure for ≈øcribing and writing again≈øt the Temporal power of the Church of Rome. I never ≈øaid Ma≈øs in any Popi≈øh Church, I am confident, the≈øe ten Years: that I have ≈øaid Ma≈øs, I won't deny. I would not tell a lye to ≈øave my own life, nay, nor would I tell a lye to take away the life of the greate≈øt Villain upon Earth. But, my Lord, I prote≈øt there is not one word true that hath been Sworn again≈øt me, but what Dr. Oates hath ≈øaid concerning my ≈øaying Ma≈øs. Oh! my Lord, I would not deny it if I were to be Hang'd pre≈øently, and is not that a great evidence of my innocence and ≈øincerity. But this does not prove that I am guilty of what I am accu≈øed for; for I am indicted upon a Penal Statute, and three things mu≈øt be proved ≈øtrictly to bring me within that Law; Fir≈øt, that I am an Engli≈øhman‚Äî

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis proved you are an Oxford≈øhire man.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: No, my Father is Lincoln≈øhire, and my Lord Chief Baron knows him.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Baron.
sp.p: I do know a Gentleman of that name there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedlow.
sp.p: I was told he was Oxford≈øhire.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: He ≈øpeaks it him≈øelf to be an Engli≈øhman. All the World knows it by your Speech.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I know my Father is ≈øo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why do you deny it your ≈øelf?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: 'Tis one thing to deny it, and another thing to have it proved ≈øo. I am not to prove it, they are.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ≈øays you are ≈øo.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p:
He talks like a Parrot: the≈øe things are to be proved ≈øtrictly; no mans life is to be taken away by pre≈øumption, which is but a Conceit in Law, and ought not to overthrow that Maxim of Law, That Penal Laws ought to be taken mo≈øt ≈øtrictly in favour of the Pri≈øoner, and I ought to be proved ad literam within the Law, and that according to the Statute made ≈øince his Maje≈øties happy Re≈øtauration, by two lawful Witne≈ø≈øes, and not only by two lawful, but by two Credible Witne≈ø≈øes too. And I ≈øuppo≈øe the Gentlemen of the Jury being apprized of this my Exception, if they will take this for truth „Äà‚óä„Äâ the≈øe men ≈øay, whom yet perhaps they would not tru≈øt for „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢ heir Shops, they do as it were wage the Law, and take it upon their Con≈øciences, that what the≈øe men ≈øay is true.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So they do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: If the≈øe things are not well proved, nothing will be proved.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: Have you any Witne≈ø≈øes that you would call?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: If you will call any, you may.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: How ≈øhall I call them, when I did not know of my Tryal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: If you will ≈øend for any Witne≈ø≈øes, the Court will ≈øtay, if they be to any thing material.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, I have again≈øt this Gentleman Mr. Dangerfield almo≈øt all the Pri≈øoners of the Kings Bench for Witne≈ø≈øes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call them, and name them.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Mr. Adderly, Mr. Puller, who can ≈øay that I never drunk a Pot of Ale with this man while he was there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who would you ≈øend for?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Tho≈øe per≈øons, to prove that I had a grudge and prejudice again≈øt this man, and that I de≈øired to be removed to Newgate for that very rea≈øon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: But the Que≈øtion is, Whether you be a Prie≈øt, or no? And you can't ≈øend for any one, that knows you, but will ≈øay, That he hath taken you for a Prie≈øt all along.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: But ≈øtill 'tis but a Pre≈øumption, not a Proof.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: The Jury is to be Judge of that, how far that goes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you expect for proof? Do you imagine there ≈øhould be no proof to convict you upon that Statute, unle≈øs we produce ≈øome Witne≈ø≈øes that actually ≈øaw you take Orders?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Yes, I ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øo, my Lord, becau≈øe Penal Statutes are to be taken ≈øtrictly.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you then, How vain would you make a Statute of England, the Laws of your Countrey? How idle a thing were it to expect any po≈ø≈øibility of proof, ≈øuch as to convict a Prie≈øt, if this be the interpretation of the Law, That no man ≈øhould be convicted by a Jury upon this Statute, but one again≈øt whom two witne≈ø≈øes ≈øhould ≈øwear they ≈øaw him take Orders? where can we find ≈øuch a Witne≈øs?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Admit that this Law were thus evaded, yet there would be no inconvenience, and I will prove it to your Lord≈øhip by Authority. It was the opinon of all the Judges, delivered about nine years agoe to the King and Council, upon a Que≈øtion about Laws again≈øt the Romi≈øh Recu≈øants, they all agreed, That this Law was only made in terrorem.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Look you Sir, you mu≈øt not talk ≈øo, it is not to be permitted.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Will you go to arraign the Judges here?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, the Kings Coun≈øell did very hone≈øtly and prudently upon that matter, for ≈øaid Sir John Keiling, 'tis very true, our Kings have not ≈øince this Law was made, put the Statute in execution unto Rigor, till you your ≈øelves occa≈øioned it: but ≈øtill the Law was a good Law, and ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary at its making, as nece≈ø≈øary as the pre≈øervation of the Queens life, and the quiet of her Dominions; and now 'tis become as nece≈ø≈øary for the pre≈øervation of the Prote≈øtant Religion, which all your Arts are employed to undermine; and more nece≈ø≈øary again, for the pre≈øervation of our Kings life, again≈øt which your contrivances are ≈øo bent.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Do you think that you ≈øhall be heard here to di≈øpute again≈øt the Law, and ≈øay it was no matter for the Law, it is a void Law, and ≈øcandalize the Judges, that they gave it for their opinion, that it was only in terrorem?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: No, I di≈øpute for the Law.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: You mu≈øt employ your time otherwi≈øe if you intend to be heard,

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Then this is that I require, I de≈øire the≈øe things may be proved, Fir≈øt that I am an Engli≈øhman, and then that I took Orders from Rome, and then that I abode here contrary to the Statute, which things in this penal Statute mu≈øt be proved.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You have upon the matter proved the fir≈øt your ≈øelf in your appeal to my Lord Chief Baron, that he knew your Father, who is a Lincoln≈øhire man.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I might be bred and born beyond Sea, tho my Father was ≈øo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you will give no proof to the contrary, a little proof will ≈øerve the Jurys turn, hearing you ≈øpeak, and knowing your Father was a Lincoln≈øhire Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: No Negative can be ≈øworn, they mu≈øt prove the affirmative.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: That will turn the proof upon you to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: A rea≈øonable proof again≈øt you, with ≈øuch probability, will put it upon you to di≈øprove it.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Look you Mr. Ander≈øon, if you have any witne≈ø≈øes to call for, or ≈øend for, the Court will give you leave to ≈øtand by a little and ≈øend for them; but if you continue to argue in this manner, the Court will give their directions to the Jury.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But Mr. Ander≈øon, the Court will do you all the Ju≈øtice that can be expected. If you have any material witne≈ø≈øes to be ≈øent for, the Court will have patience till they come; but then you mu≈øt be ≈øure they are material witne≈ø≈øes, for we will not go to loo≈øe time upon a bare ≈øurmi≈øe. If it be only to prove this Negative, that Mr. Dangerfield was never in your company in the Kings-Bench, it will ≈øignify nothing, for there are three witne≈ø≈øes without him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Have you any witne≈ø≈øes to prove that you were born beyond Sea, or any thing that is material, we will ≈øtay for them.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Ellys.
sp.p: There is nothing now in que≈øtion, but whether you be an Engli≈øhman and a Prie≈øt; and if you can prove that you are not ≈øo, you ≈øay well. But I think you deny not now but that you are a Prie≈øt, only you would have us prove that you are an Engli≈øhman. Your Speech betrays you, and there is ≈øo much Evidence again≈øt you, that I have not heard in any Ca≈øe as I know of. And all your Witne≈ø≈øes will be to little purpo≈øe.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: Only this I de≈øire to ob≈øerve, That I have been a man always countenanced by the be≈øt of Kings, and His Privy Council; and if the Parliament had not been di≈ø≈øolved, I had been protected by the Parliament: Now I ≈øay, if your Lord≈øhips think me worthy of any con≈øideration (as I have been a man that have given ≈øeveral te≈øtimonies of my Loyalty, and Obedience to the Government) I de≈øire your Lord≈øhips would plea≈øe to ≈øtay till you know the Kings plea≈øure.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You know where you mu≈øt apply your ≈øelf for that, we are barely upon our Oaths, and ≈øo is the Jury too, to try the Fact, whether you be a Prie≈øt; and this I will tell you, and I mu≈øt ≈øay to you, I dare appeal to your own Con≈øcience, whether this I≈ø≈øue, your being a Romi≈øh Prie≈øt, is not as plainly and evidently proved, to the ≈øatisfaction of all mankind, as any thing can be?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: But 'tis all by pre≈øumption ≈øtill.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Well, Gentlemen of the Jury, the matter that he in≈øi≈øts upon, are Two things; Fir≈øt, ≈øays he, You have not proved me to be an Engli≈øhman, and yet at the ≈øame time he appeals to ≈øuch as knew his Father, to be an Engli≈øh Gentleman; and his Language, his Tongue betrays him. 'Tis true, ≈øome kind of Evidence is to be given, that he is an Engli≈øhman, he him≈øelf tels you, that he is born of Engli≈øh Parents; but 'tis a forreign
matter, that he ≈øhould be born beyond Sea. And if it were ≈øo really, then it comes on his ≈øide, if he can produce any witne≈øs he ≈øays ≈øomething, otherwi≈øe we leave it to you, whether you are not ≈øatisfied in your Con≈øciences, by hearing him ≈øpeak, and under≈øtanding who his Father was, that he is an Engli≈øhman. The next thing is for his being a Prie≈øt: I do not know, nor can there be expected a plainer proof than this that hath been given, becau≈øe he doth tho≈øe Acts which none but a Prie≈øt among≈øt them does; he ≈øays Ma≈øs, he Con≈øecrates the Sacrament, he takes Confe≈ø≈øion, he gives Ab≈øolution, and all this proved by Four Witne≈ø≈øes.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: That the Clerk does at Ma≈øs, give Ab≈øolution.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Does, or can any but a Prie≈øt Ab≈øolve?

sp.speaker: D. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, the Clerk, he that ≈øerves at Ma≈øs at that time, gives pro forma Ab≈øolution to the Prie≈øt, without which, the Prie≈øt cannot approach to the Altar, after he hath made a general Confe≈ø≈øion for the whole Congregation, the Clerk ab≈øolves the Prie≈øt, that he may Ab≈øolve the Congregation.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, the Fact is plain upon you, we mu≈øt never expect to convict a Prie≈øt upon this Statute, if ≈øuch proof is not ≈øufficient.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: He does acknowledge that Doctor Oates hath heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Go on to the next.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: The next we will Try, ≈øhall be James Corker, with whom the Jury was charged as with the other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, and you Gentleman of the Jury; James Corker, the Pri≈øoner at the Bar, ≈øtands Indicted for High Trea≈øon, for that being born within the Kings Dominions, and made a Prie≈øt by Authority from the See of Rome, did traiterou≈øly come and abide in England, contrary to the Law. To this he hath pleaded Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, call your Witne≈ø≈øes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: Doctor Oates, Mr. Bedloe, and Mr. Praunce, (who were all ≈øworn) Doctor Oates, pray tell my Lord, and the≈øe Gentlemen, what you know of this Mr. Corkers being a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he hath ≈øaid Ma≈øs at Somer≈øet-Hou≈øe, and before the Proclamation and Declaration in 1674. made again≈øt the Catholicks, he was one of the Queens Prie≈øts, he is a Benedictine Monk, and he hath ≈øaid Ma≈øs at Somer≈øet-Hou≈øe; and I have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs at the Savoy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In a Prie≈øts Habit?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I have ≈øeen him in a Monks Habit.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you ever ≈øeen him give the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I received the Sacrament from him my ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: In the Savoy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he Con≈øecrate the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Not that that I received, I cannot ≈øay whether he did or no.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do any Admini≈øter the Sacrament but Prie≈øts?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: They are in Orders fir≈øt. And 'tis again≈øt the Laws of the Church for any but Prie≈øts to do it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: None u≈øe to do it but Prie≈øts, doe they?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cann't tell; but he that I took it from, I always took to be a Prie≈øt: be≈øides, I ≈øaw his Patent to be Bi≈øhop of London, and they don't u≈øe to make them Bi≈øhops before they be Prie≈øts.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he ≈øhew it you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I ≈øaw it.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: From whom was that Patent?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: It was from the See of Rome.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: Under what Seal was it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cann't tell that, but I remember that I ≈øaw the Patent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, will you ask him any thing?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: When was it that you heard me ≈øay Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: The fir≈øt time that I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs, is near upon Three years agoe, and then I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs about the la≈øt winter was Two years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often have you heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Several times, a dozen times I believe.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: Was there any body with you when you heard me ≈øay Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I believe there was an whole Church full at Somer≈øet-Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: Can you nominate any in particular?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: How can he do that? He ≈øays there was an whole Church full.

sp.speaker: M. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Will you ask him any more Que≈øtions?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: Then ≈øet up Mr. Bedloe. Pray Sir, will you tell my Lord and the Jury, what you know of Mr. Corker's being a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I have ≈øeen him wear the Habit of a Benedictine Monk, before the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Covent in the Savoy: and I have ≈øeen him Confe≈ø≈øing ≈øeveral people in Somer≈øet-Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And gave them Ab≈øolution?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Doe they u≈øe to let them ≈øee when they confe≈øs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: They confe≈øs in publick, but they ≈øpeak ≈øo ≈øoftly we cann't hear, but the whole Chappel ≈øometimes may be full of people Confe≈ø≈øing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: About four or five years ≈øince, when Father Lathum was there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ever hear him ≈øay Ma≈øs at Father Lathum's?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, I never ≈øaw him ≈øay Ma≈øs, but only Confe≈øs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you never ≈øee him deliver the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: When you ≈øaw me in my Habit, Was it when you came to Father Lathum's?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I Judge ≈øo it was ≈øeveral times, with ≈øeveral of them.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: Can you nominate any one that ≈øaw me at the ≈øame time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: There were a whole Chappel full of Catholicks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: That is no great matter whether he can or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Atkins.
sp.p: 'Tis an Immaterial Que≈øtion, Why do you ask it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: My Lord, What I did, was done ≈øo privately, that if I went but from Strand-Bridge to the Monks, I either took a Boat and went by Water, or a Coach and went round about to avoid Su≈øpition.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Then ≈øet up Mr. Prance. Pray Sir tell what you know of this.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: I have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs at Mr. Pastons in Dukestreet.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Never but once.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: When Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: It may be two years agoe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Atkyns.
sp.p: That is another place too, Mr. Corker.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any thing to Ask him?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What have you then to ≈øay for your ≈øelf?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: My Lord, this I have to ≈øay for my ≈øelf, and I do prote≈øt it to be true, I never in my life did ever ≈øay Ma≈øs, or hear Confe≈ø≈øions at Somer≈øet-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ≈øay you to Mr. Paston's?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: No, nor at Mr. Pa≈øton's, nor ever was in the Company of that Man, nor ever ≈øaw him here in my life to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That may be.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: I likewi≈øe prote≈øt, that I never ≈øaid Ma≈øs in any publick place ≈øince I was borne.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It may be, you count not Mr. Pa≈øton's a publick place.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: If it be a private place, then I ≈øhould know who were in the Company, and who were admitted there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, you were not 2 or 3 years ago ≈øo nice, and cautious whom you admitted to ≈øee you in the Exerci≈øe of what you call your Religion; becau≈øe the Execution of the Law was not ≈øo ≈øtrict, as now adays it is. And therefore 'tis very probable, and may very well be, that you were at Mr. Pa≈øtons Hou≈øe, and yet not know all the Company.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: But, I ≈øay, I never did ≈øay Ma≈øs there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Pemberton.
sp.p: Here are three Witne≈ø≈øes again≈øt you, and do you think your bare Word will be taken again≈øt their three Oaths?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: What ≈øay you to the Savoy Mr. Corker? and I ask you, becau≈øe I would know whether you can ≈øpeak Truth in any thing.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: I ≈øay, as to the Savoy, I never received any one Confe≈ø≈øion there. And I do prote≈øt I never ≈øaid Ma≈øs, nor heard Confe≈ø≈øion in Somer≈øet-hou≈øe, nor at Mr. Paston's in Dukes-≈øtreet. And, as for the Savoy, I humbly beg, that ≈øince the denyal of it will not clear me, I may not be my own Accu≈øer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen of the Jury, you hear what is proved again≈øt him by three Witne≈ø≈øes, that they heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs, and receive Confe≈ø≈øions, and deliver the Sacrament. They tell you what Order he was of, and that they ≈øaw him do the Acts of a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: I appeal to all the World that ever came to Somer≈øet-hou≈øe, Whether ever any one heard me ≈øay Ma≈øs there?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here is one hath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serjeant Strode.
sp.p: We will Try William Mar≈øhall next, who was charged upon the Jury as the others.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury, William Mar≈øhall, the Pri≈øoner at the Bar, ≈øtands Indicted for High-Trea≈øon. The Offence is not for being a Prie≈øt barely, but that he being born an Engli≈øhman, within the Kings Dominions, and having received Orders from Rome, did, again≈øt the Laws of the Kingdom, come and abide here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serjeant Strode.
sp.p: Swear Dr. Oates, and Mr. Bedloe (which was done) Dr. Oates, pray ≈øtand up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can you ≈øay to Mr. Mar≈øhall's being a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs in the Savoy, and I have ≈øeen him in that po≈øture that the Prie≈øts are in when they give Ab≈øolution.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you ≈øeen him in a Prie≈øts Habit ≈øay Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, in his Habit, as a Benedictine Monk.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Jones.
sp.p: Did you ever ≈øee him give the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, and Con≈øecrate the Ho≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: Well, Have you any thing to ask him?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhal.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I have known him the≈øe three years to be a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: That is a year longer then you knew me at the Tryall.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: It is a great while ≈øince that Tryal.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, that is a good while ago.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: But where Mr. Oates, and when?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: At the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Within the compa≈øs of three years ≈øeveral times.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: How does that afford me any occa≈øion of Defence? I can make no Plea, unle≈øs he a≈øcertains time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: 'Tis good Evidence, without confining him≈øelf to preci≈øe time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ≈øays a Dozen times within that Compa≈øs.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: But why does he not name ≈øome particular time, for unle≈øs he name the time, How is it po≈ø≈øible for us to di≈øprove him?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He tells you many times in three years.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: But when?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why within three years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: What if he could tell you when?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis an improper Que≈øtion that you Ask.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: He is not bound to name the day.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Well, I will pitch upon a day now.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Several times la≈øt Summer was Twelve-Moneth.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: What before the Plot?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Did you hear me ≈øay Ma≈øs before you went over to Spain?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Dolben.
sp.p: Call another Witne≈øs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Mr. Bedloe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serjeant Strode.
sp.p: Pray will you tell what you know of Mr. Mar≈øhall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I know a great deal of him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What of his being a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I have ≈øeen him in his Habit, of a Benedictine Monk in the Savoy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I have not: But he hath been preparing to go to take Confe≈ø≈øions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he own him≈øelf to be a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: He was in the Habit of a Prie≈øt, but I never ≈øaw him execute any part of the Office of a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Pemberton.
sp.p: Did you hear him declare, that he hath been going at any time to take Confe≈ø≈øion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: The Monks have ≈øaid, when he hath been gone, that he went to take Confe≈ø≈øions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Upon your Oath, Have you ever heard him own him≈øelf to be a Prie≈øt, or ever ≈øay, that he was going to take Confe≈ø≈øion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, my Lord, but I have ≈øeen him in a Monks Habit, and within half an hour he was in a Secular Habit: for when they went abroad they took Confe≈ø≈øions in their Secular Habit.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often have you ≈øeen him in a Monks Habit?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I do not know whether it were more then once. And I Asked then, Where is our Father going?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: And what ≈øaid they to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: He was going to take Confe≈ø≈øions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Dolben.
sp.p: Have not you your ≈øelf been Confe≈ø≈øed by Mar≈øhall?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ≈øay you to him, will you Ask him any Que≈øtions?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I do not I think need to Ask this VVitne≈øs any Que≈øtions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That ≈øhall be ob≈øerved for you, if it be to your advantage. If you have any thing to ≈øay for your ≈øelf, pray ≈øpeak it.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: If there be but one Witne≈øs, VVhat need I make any Defence?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat ≈øay you to Mr. Oates Te≈øtimony?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: As for Mr. Oates, if your Lord≈øhip will but promie, that it ≈øhall not prejudice me, as to the point of having but one VVitne≈øs, I have much to ≈øay for my ≈øelf: But, I think I need not trouble your Lord≈øhip with it.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: VVere not you here when Mar≈øhall was Tryed for the Plot?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: You mu≈øt not Ask him any Que≈øtions about that.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I ≈øay, if your Lord≈øhip will but grant, that the VVitne≈ø≈øes may have free Acce≈øs, and go away ≈øafe‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I believe the Court, upon his Tryal, was ≈øatisfied that he was in Orders, received from the Church of Rome.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Prance (which was done) What did you hear him ≈øay at his la≈øt Tryal?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is hard Evidence truely.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Jones.
sp.p: If he would do it voluntarily of him≈øelf, he might, we did not Ask him the Que≈øtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: My Lord, I ≈øtood ju≈øt by him when he ≈øtood at the Bar, and I heard him ≈øay this to the other Man Mr. Corker, Though we are Priests, this does not reach us.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But is this Good Evidence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: I did hear him ≈øay, He was a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: VVe did all hear him ≈øay ≈øo I believe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Atkyns.
sp.p: I dare ≈øay none of the Court Asked him the Que≈øtion.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I was not Asked, nor had any occa≈øion, and certainly I ≈øhould not pick an occa≈øion to Condemn my ≈øelf. If I did it, I did it without occa≈øion. Be≈øides, my Lord, I humbly conceive, that there mu≈øt be proof again≈øt a man, or his Confe≈ø≈øion won't make him Guilty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: I would not have you too ≈øure of that.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Certainly if a Man do Confe≈øs at another time, without proof again≈øt him that will not do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: I believe the Jury will take your own Confe≈ø≈øion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Don't be over Confident of that, for we have Memories too a≈øwell as you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: You are not beli'd by Mr. Prance, I believe, Mr. Mar≈øhall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Ellis.
sp.p: If he have confe≈øs'd it, that is ≈øure proof enough.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Dugdale. (which was done) You were at the la≈øt Tryal, Sir, I only ask of you, Can you remember any thing of this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: To the be≈øt of my remembrance, I heard him own that he was a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: Then ≈øay what you can for your ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I have only one material Witne≈øs again≈øt me. They ≈øay that I ≈øaid ≈øo; if I did ≈øay ≈øo, I mu≈øt ≈øay it to the Court, and if it was to the Court, it mu≈øt be upon ≈øome Que≈øtion asked me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You mu≈øt not ≈øay ≈øo; I am afraid if you appeal to the Court, it will do you no good.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: It is plain that you are ≈øo free of your di≈øcour≈øe, that you might ≈øay things that were not pertinent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis not proper for the Court to give Evidence; if we did, we ≈øhould do you little Service in this matter.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I do believe I ≈øhall receive all Ju≈øtice from the Court. And I have experienced it ≈øo already. Now as to the pre≈øent Te≈øtimony again≈øt me, I conceive that only Mr. Oates is a material Witne≈øs; no one el≈øe ≈øwears that they ever ≈øaw me Officiate or perform the Duty of a Prie≈øt. As for Mr. Oates, he ≈øays he heard me ≈øay Ma≈øs ≈øeveral times the la≈øt Summer before the Plot. And Mr. Oates did ≈øay he was pre≈øent in June, July, and Augu≈øt. Sir William Waller, though he was plea≈øed to forget other things, yet did remember that, and did Te≈øtifie that he ≈øaw me in June, July, and Augu≈øt. Now then I humbly conceive, if he heard me ≈øay Ma≈øs at any time in that Summer, it mu≈øt be in one of tho≈øe three Months. Was it in any one of them?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I came over in April from Saint Omers, and I did, as I remember, hear him ≈øay Ma≈øs one time before I went again, and heard him ≈øay it ≈øeveral times after, which was about the middle of June, I think.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Now I ≈øay, if this Honourable Court will but plea≈øe to promi≈øe, that the Witne≈ø≈øes that come hither ≈øhall come and go ≈øafe, I believe there are Witne≈ø≈øes that may contradict Dr. Oates.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can your Witne≈ø≈øes prove? you mu≈øt not make bargains with the Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Why ≈øhould you ≈øu≈øpect that your Witne≈ø≈øes ≈øhould not go free?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Becau≈øe ≈øome have received great abu≈øes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: It was ≈øo ≈øaid, but not made out.

sp.speaker: M. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: There was only one per≈øon that came here, and affirmed ≈øo, but he did not prove it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: And the Court did ≈øay that they ≈øhould be puni≈øhed that did it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The witne≈ø≈øes none of them, that I know of, were abu≈øed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: It was only the Kings witne≈ø≈øes that have been abu≈øed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can your witne≈ø≈øes prove.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: He came over the 24th. of April, and I can prove that from the beginning of April to the end of July, I was not within three≈øcore Miles of London.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: As to his Officiating as a Prie≈øt, I cannot ≈øpeak po≈øitively as to the time, but I think in la≈øt Summer was twelve Month.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: He ≈øays, he thinks he did once in that time, but he is ≈øure, that he did ≈øee you ≈øeveral times that Summer.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: But what part of the Summer?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: From the time of my coming over again, to the time of the Di≈øcovery of the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was it that you heard him fir≈øt.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: When I heard him fir≈øt was in the year 1677. before I went into Spain: I went away in the Month of April, and I am ≈øure he ≈øaid Ma≈øs before I went into Spain; and when I came back again in the Winter, I came in November, and ≈øtay'd in Town about ten days, and then went to the Savoy and heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: What November?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Before the Summer I came out of Flanders.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ≈øays he went into Spain in April, (77.)

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: And he heard me ≈øay Ma≈øs before he went over?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Pray look, my Lord, Mr. Oates will confe≈øs him≈øelf, he was but newly reconcil'd to the Church of Rome a little while before he went.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I was reconcil'd to the Church on A≈øh-wedne≈øday, and I went in April following.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Where did you hear me ≈øay Ma≈øs then?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: In the Savoy, at that time before I went into Spain.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Do you pretend to have known the Savoy ever before your coming back again?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: He does Swear it.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: So he does, but he can't prove it. Mr. Oates came over in the Company, as he ≈øays, of Mr. Thimbleby and Mr. Hitchcock, and by his means he did get to be commended to be received into the Order of the Benedictines, and he was then ≈øent to Mr. Pickering in order to it; Now, my Lord, is it credible that Mr. Oates having no acquaintance with the Savoy before he had acquaintance with Mr. Hitchock, which was when he came from Spain, ≈øhould hear me ≈øay Ma≈øs before he went thither?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: All this is but a Story to the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What a wild inference do you make from this un-intelligible bu≈øine≈øs?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Mr. Oates ≈øays ≈øo him≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: We all know you ≈øaid Ma≈øs ≈øo openly in the Savoy, that any People what≈øoever might come, and you did not know who they were.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Though he was not one of your Order, yet he might know you.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: To my knowledge there was never three Ma≈ø≈øes ≈øaid in the World at the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: The World knows the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Let Mr. Oates be po≈øitive in any thing, and we will di≈øprove him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: He hath gone as near it as is nece≈ø≈øary; he tells you, after his Reconciliation, before he went over into Spain.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: But I ≈øay, he could not be at the Savoy before he was acquainted there, and I can bring Witne≈ø≈øes to prove, that I was not then at the Savoy; but I pray, my Lord, will the≈øe Witne≈ø≈øes do me any good?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What will they prove?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: That all the Summer, from the beginning of April to the end of the Summer, I was in the Countrey, three≈øcore Miles from London.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I am not ≈øo po≈øitive in that, my Lord, but as near as I remember, before I went into Spain again. Your Lord≈øhips all know that I was not ≈øo po≈øitive as to any one time; but the Summer before the Plot broke out, I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs ≈øeveral times in the Summer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now he is po≈øitive that he ≈øaw you ≈øay Ma≈øs in the Summer before the Plot was di≈øcovered. The ≈øub≈øtance of his Depo≈øition was your ≈øaying Ma≈øs, the time is not material: he tells of a many times within that compa≈øs.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: How ≈øhall I di≈øprove that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: He hath given you one particular time from A≈øhwedne≈øday, when he was reconciled to Rome, till he went to Spain in April.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: If he names times, then am I able to di≈øprove him: and he did name one, but when he ≈øaw me offer to prove by Witne≈ø≈øes, That I was not then in Town, he goes off from it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: 'Tis impo≈ø≈øible for Witne≈ø≈øes to be po≈øitive to a day, a week, or ≈øuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Ellis.
sp.p: How is it po≈ø≈øible to be ≈øo, unle≈øs it be a thing that he had taken ≈øuch particular notice of, as to intend to Swear to it, and give Evidence about it afterwards. Now, I believe, Dr. Oates at that time had no thoughts of giving Evidence as to any ≈øuch matter; but this he is po≈øitive in, That he did hear you ≈øay Ma≈øs at the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord, if Mr. Oates had ≈øaid he had ≈øeen me Officiate at Somer≈øet-hou≈øe, or Wild-hou≈øe, it might have been ≈øomething like; but at the Savoy, it is known, That none are let in but Friends, nor could Mr. Oates come in, but upon a particular acquaintance.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How does that appear ≈øo?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: By tho≈øe that live in the hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: You mu≈øt not ≈øpend the Courts time in this manner of di≈øcour≈øe. If you have any Witne≈ø≈øes that you think in your ≈øelf are material, the Court will ≈øuffer you to call them, and pray call them pre≈øently.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Here is the Hou≈øe-keeper her ≈øelf that will witne≈øs, That ≈øhe never ≈øaw Mr. Oates there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If the great Turk had come there with apair of Beads and a Crucifix, you would have let him come in. But in the mean time, Mr. Oates, you have given him a pretty compa≈øs of time, whereby he hath an opportunity of di≈øproving of what you ≈øay. And you give him one particular ≈øhort time, but can you give any time afterwards in the Summer you ≈øpeak of, within any Month, or two, or three. Becau≈øe you ≈øay at ≈øeveral times.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cannot be po≈øitive, but I will tell you one time was the Sunday before they held their Con≈øpiracy, which was, I verily believe, the Sunday before the 21th of Augu≈øt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you believe it was in Augu≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I do, and confine my ≈øelf to the Month of Augu≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Then call Ellen Rigby.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I was acquainted with Mr. Pickering ≈øoon after my being reconciled, and being acquainted with him, I went along with him ≈øeveral times to the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: What do you talk of one Hitchcock, and I know not whom, he was acquainted with Pickering before.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: VVhen, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pre≈øently after he was reconciled.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: VVell, but you pretend now, that ≈øince you came over here, you were in the Savoy; Had you a Key to get in?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He was reconciled on A≈øhwedne≈øday, he went in April to Spain.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Here is Ellen Rigby.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVell, what would you have with her?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I ask, Did ≈øhe ever ≈øee Mr. Oates in the Summer before la≈øt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Don't you lead your VVitne≈øs with ≈øuch Que≈øtions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: I have ≈øeen him when I ≈øee him come to ask Charity of Mr. Pickering.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Twice or Thrice.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat time in the Summer?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: I cannot ≈øay, but I ≈øaw him in Summer was Twelve-month.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Why then did not this Woman, when ≈øhe knew this Evidence that would lay a blemi≈øh upon me, come and give it for Pickering to have ≈øaved him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: Will you give me leave to ask this Woman this Que≈øtion. Whether ≈øhe ever heard you ≈øay Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, with all my heart; and if ≈øhe ≈øays ≈øhe hath, I will be hang'd without any more ado.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: Then you are ≈øure your Pro≈øelytes will ≈øay any thing you would have them?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I my ≈øelf am a perfect ≈øtranger to the Savoy in a manner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Is he not acquainted with the Savoy?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Yes, he was there one Month, when Pickering was taken.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Pray ask her whether ever, before Mr. Oates went over, ≈øhe ≈øaw him in the Savoy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ≈øhall have your Que≈øtion asked, but do you think you can build upon that, if ≈øhe did not ≈øee him, he did not ≈øee you. Did you ever ≈øee Dr. Oates there betwixt March and April, before he went over into Spain?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: No, there was no body in the hou≈øe but Mr. Pickering.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was there never Ma≈øs ≈øaid in the Hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Yes, while her Maje≈øties Servants were in the hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But was there Ma≈øs never ≈øaid ≈øince in the hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Never ≈øince I came out of it, which was a Twelve-month ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Was there not Ma≈øs ≈øaid in three or four years time there?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Not in our hou≈øe, I lived but in one hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I call her to know whether Dr. Oates was there? And my Lord, here is that which I in≈øi≈øt upon, That none is let in there to hear Ma≈øs, but tho≈øe that have ≈øome particular acquaintance and intimacy in the hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: She only ≈øpeaks to one particular part of the hou≈øe. She can't ≈øay but Ma≈øs was ≈øaid in the other parts.

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: There was no Ma≈øs ≈øaid there, that I know of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, was there no Ma≈øs ≈øaid, but in that particular hou≈øe you lived in?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: I can't ≈øay that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But the Que≈øtion is, whether ever you, Mr. Oates, ≈øaw him ≈øay Ma≈øs in this womans hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I do not know that ever I ≈øaw this woman in all my life, before the Tryal.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: He came there under a di≈øgui≈øed name.
