sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He tells you he went along with Pickering.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Pickering ≈øerved the Ma≈øs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, call your Witne≈ø≈øes, if you have any other.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I can prove that I was out of Town the whole Summer, from the beginning of April to the end of the Summer. But if Mr. Oates will not ≈øtand to any time, I cannot be able to di≈øprove him. But then Ile only offer one or two things more.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you come to London, in Augu≈øt?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I will tell you as near as I can to a day. I came in the middle of Bartholomew Fair, which begins the 24th of Augu≈øt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So it was the latter end.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Well, if you have any Witne≈ø≈øes, call them, and do not ≈øpend the Courts time in vain.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p:
My Lord, I have ≈øomething very material, I think, to offer. The only material Witne≈øs that is now again≈øt me, was a Witne≈øs again≈øt me in my la≈øt Tryal; now I do conceive that I being found, Not Guilty at the la≈øt Tryal, that Witne≈øs ought to be look'd
upon as Perjured. And I appeal to the Court, whether it were ≈øo or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: That's a fal≈øe Collection, Mr. Mar≈øhall.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis a ≈øtrange inference you make, Do you think, that every Witne≈øs is Perjured, becau≈øe the Jury don't find according to what he ≈øays? He is not Perjured, for he may Swear true, and the Jury not believe him.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I ground it my Lord, upon what my Lord Jones ≈øaid to the Jury that Sate upon Coleman, who at their going out told them, Either they were to find him Guilty, or bring in two men Perjured. Thus it was his opinion, that the finding of the Jury contrary to the Evidence, did make them perjured; and there was none of the Court did oppo≈øe him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: And if this were the ≈øen≈øe of the whole Court, That a man mu≈øt either be found Guilty, or the Witne≈ø≈øes Perjured, that is my Ca≈øe, and he is not to be believed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: See how uncon≈øequently do you talk. The Court might ≈øay, That you mu≈øt believe the≈øe men Perjured, if they Swear a po≈øitive thing, and you find it not; but if you make u≈øe of it thus, that therefore they are Perjured, 'tis fal≈øe, for they are not ≈øo, till they be Convicted upon Record. And though the Jury do not believe them, yet they may Swear true.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you make no inference from it.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I am before the ≈øame Court that I was tryed by before, and before the ≈øelf-≈øame Judges, who know that upon my Tryal he was not believed, and therefore is perjured.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: You mu≈øt con≈øider, that ≈øometimes the Jury will go again≈øt the direction of the Court; but if the Witne≈øs be not believed by them, that does not argue that he does not Swear truth, or is perjured. I tell you, My Brother Jones might ≈øay, You mu≈øt find this man Guilty, or think the≈øe men Perjured: many times a Judge will ≈øay ≈øo, but the Jury often find again≈øt the direction of the Court; Shall the≈øe men be perjured then pre≈øently?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: There was two po≈øitive Witne≈ø≈øes, as po≈øitive as could be in the world, and nothing at all to contradict them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Will you give the Jury leave to believe you Mr. Mar≈øhall? for you your ≈øelf ≈øaid, you were a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Yes, if I ≈øaid ≈øo. I humbly de≈øire the Jury to take notice of it, that they are the ≈øelf ≈øame Witne≈ø≈øes that brought ≈øuch a po≈øitive Te≈øtimony the la≈øt time, which if the Jury had believed, they mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity have brought me in Guilty; I would not ≈øpend the time of the Court, but I would ob≈øerve this, It was all Sworn po≈øitively, That I did con≈øent to the Kings Death, and other things.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You had the better luck.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Then they are not to be believed now.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
This is to no purpo≈øe, neither is it to be ≈øuffered: For you break in contrary to all the Laws of Practice, if we ≈øuffer this as an Argument, That becau≈øe an Evidence was not believed in one
Ca≈øe, therefore he is Perjured: And the Jury gave in a Verdict contrary to the Witne≈ø≈øes Te≈øtimony, that therefore he is Perjured in another Ca≈øe.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: This does invalidate the Te≈øtimony ≈øure of ≈øuch a Witne≈øs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You have ≈øaid it often enough, come pray conclude.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: No, Mr. Mar≈øhall, you mu≈øt not be ≈øuffered in the≈øe Harangues to impeach the Witne≈ø≈øes; if you have any thing material again≈øt Dr. Oates, or if you can ≈øhew any Record of his Conviction of Perjury, it may be ≈øomething.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord, it is for my Life, and 'tis the ≈øecond time that I plead for my Life, much beyond my expectation; and therefore I hope I may have the freedom to ≈øpeak. And though I confe≈øs this Jury is not obliged to proceed according to the Verdict of the former Jury, yet this Jury, as well as that, is obliged to proceed according to the appearance of truth. And his being found fal≈øe in his Te≈øtimony the la≈øt time, ≈øhould make him of no Credit here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: It is not ≈øo, they are not to take notice of it, unle≈øs you bring them a Record of Conviction.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: He gave a good Evidence then no doubt of it, though they would not believe it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: Upon what grounds that Jury went, is unknown to us.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, another thing is this. The Law does except again≈øt all Witne≈ø≈øes who are ≈øtrongly or rationally ≈øuppo≈øed to have a Spight or Malice again≈øt the Pri≈øoner, much more where there is a manife≈øt ≈øign that he hath a Malice. Now I will endeavour to ≈øhew how it comes to my Ca≈øe: Mr. Oates accu≈øed me la≈øt time of Trea≈øon, and that in the highe≈øt nature; if this had been true, he had ≈øhewed him≈øelf a good Subject, and me Di≈øloyal. And the Jury not believing him, I was found the good Subject. Now he pur≈øues his Malice.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ≈øhall not go on in this manner, and make ≈øuch notorious fal≈øe inferences, that becau≈øe it was not found according to his Te≈øtimony, therefore he is Perjured. The Jury did not beleive it, might not he ≈øpeak true for all that? Hath not many a Witne≈øs Sworn true, yet the Verdict gone again≈øt their Evidence? and therefore you don't mind, Ye are all guiddy-headed, if you once get a thing into your heads, you can't get it out again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Atkins.
sp.p: If the Jury did not believe it, a great many others did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: All you build upon is but a fal≈øe Conclu≈øion; becau≈øe the Jury found you not Guilty, therefore they found him Perjured.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord,‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Pray Sir, if you will ≈øpeak any thing that is material and mode≈øt, the Court will admit you to it; but if you only go to throw dirt upon the Kings Witne≈ø≈øes, men of good Reputation, and men that have ≈øhewed them≈øelves hone≈øt, and that have ≈øpoke truth all along, ne're a one of their Te≈øtimonies but what is confirmed by anothers, ≈øo that not one of them ≈øtands ≈øingle, and for you to ≈øay they are ill men.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I do not ≈øay they are ill men, I ≈øpeak of matter of Fact.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You conclude fal≈øly, and if you did but mind it, you would never repeat it over and over again. That becau≈øe the Jury did not believe his Evidence, therefore he is Perjured. Do you ≈øuppo≈øe then that any other Jury ≈øhould never believe him?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I reckon his Evidence is not ≈øo good, and if I am found Not Guilty, there mu≈øt be malice in him to accu≈øe me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Look you Gentlemen, The ≈øingle Que≈øtion is, Whether he be a Romi≈øh Prie≈øt or no? it is proved by Mr. Oates that he hath ≈øeveral times heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs, that he hath ≈øeen him deliver the Sacrament, and ≈øeen him Con≈øecrate the Ho≈øt. He in≈øi≈øted upon it how often, Mr. Oates ≈øays, Ten or a Dozen times, in what time he cannot charge him≈øelf particularly with a Month or two; but at la≈øt he did tell him po≈øitively, becau≈øe Mar≈øhall ≈øaid, how is it po≈ø≈øible I can make my defence to generals unle≈øs you fix ≈øometime? therefore ≈øays he, I was Reconciled to the Church of Rome on A≈øh-Wedne≈øday, and afterwards between that and April, when I went into Spain, I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs, that was once. But I heard him ≈øay in the Summer ≈øeveral times. Being asked what part, he ≈øays, I cannot ≈øay exactly, but I think in the Month of Augu≈øt; If he had ≈øaid any thing as to the particular time, between A≈øh-Wedne≈øday and his going into Spain it had been ≈øomething, but again≈øt that he makes no pretence, as to his ≈øaying Ma≈øs in the Savoy, that can contradict it. If he can ≈øtill, he ≈øhall call his Witne≈ø≈øes that can prove he did not ≈øay Ma≈øs between the A≈øh-Wedne≈øday, and the April he went into Spain. He does indeed ≈øay, that he was a great part of the Summer in the Countrey, in June, and July, to Bartholomew Fair, Three≈øcore Miles off, but to that, Mr. Oates ≈øays it was ≈øometime in Augu≈øt and ≈øo he might be in the Countrey till then, and yet ≈øay Ma≈øs after, he might come to Town the 6th, or 7th, or Eight and Twentieth, and he might be here in Augu≈øt. So you hear no Evidence that contradicts ≈øuppo≈øing it proved true, what he imagines his Witne≈ø≈øes can ≈øay. The la≈øt time that he charges him to have ≈øaid it in the Summer, may be true according to his own word and Confe≈ø≈øion when he came to Town. Then there is Mr. Bedloe, he only tells you he ≈øaw him in a Prie≈øts habit, but he did not ≈øee him Execute the Office of a Prie≈øt, but he looked upon him as a Prie≈øt, called him Father; and that is all that he Charges him with, that is concurring Evidence, and backs Mr. Oates; but alone perhaps it would be very weak. But they ≈øet up here Prance, and he ≈øays directly, that at the Tryal, he did confe≈øs him≈øelf to be a Prie≈øt; and he ≈øeems to deny it, and would appeal to the Court; but his appealing to the Court would not help him in that Ca≈øe. So I leave this to you upon this Evidence, if you believe Mr. Oates that Swears he ≈øaw him before he went into Spain, and after ≈øay Ma≈øs with the concurring Evidence of Mr. Bedloe that ≈øaw him in his Habit, and with the ≈øub≈øequent Evidence of tho≈øe two more that do Swear that he did ≈øay ≈øo, you mu≈øt find him Guilty. And a mans own
Confe≈ø≈øion is Evidence again≈øt him≈øelf. And if Mr. Mar≈øhall will recollect him≈øelf, he would not be too po≈øitive in that point. If all the≈øe particulars ≈øatisfie your Con≈øcience, I ≈øay, that he is a Romi≈øh Prie≈øt, you mu≈øt find him Guilty, if you are un≈øatisfied you mu≈øt acquit him.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set William Ru≈ø≈øel to the Bar. William Ru≈ø≈øel alias Napper, hold up thy hand: You that are Sworn, look upon the Pri≈øoner, and hearken to his Cau≈øe, &c.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury, William Ru≈ø≈øel ali√°s Napper, ≈øtands Indicted for High Trea≈øon. The Offence Charged in the Indictment is, That being born within the Kingdom of England, and having received Orders from the See of Rome, he did come and abide here. To this he hath pleaded, Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: Swear Dr. Oates and Mr. Prance. Dr. Oates, will you tell my Lord and the Jury, what you know of Mr. Ru≈ø≈øels being a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, this Ru≈ø≈øel went by the name of Napper, and is a Franci≈øcan Fryer, and I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs ≈øeveral times at Wild-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What in his Habit?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: In Prie≈øts Habit.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: The la≈øt Summer before the Plot, I have heard him Twenty times ≈øing Ma≈øs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: Did you ever ≈øee him give the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: Where, pray was this?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: At Wild-Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: What is his Name?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Oates.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: I do not know him I ≈øay, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he do it publickly?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, in the Chappel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: Did he give the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I did receive the Sacrament from him.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: Why, fir≈øt of all, I ≈øay I do not know him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It may be ≈øo, more know Jack Pudding, than Jack Pudding knows.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: Well then if one Witne≈øs mu≈øt ≈øtand, I have no more to ≈øay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Que≈øtions?

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: He ≈øays he heard me a Month ago.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No it was la≈øt Summer was twelve Month.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: Then he mu≈øt prove it.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richard≈øon.
sp.p: He does prove it, he Swears it.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: Well, I can make it appear, la≈øt Summer was twelve Month I was in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: And I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs, November 1677. he was then one of the Chaplains of Wild-Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: Give me leave to recollect my Memory.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Set up Mr. Prance. You hear the Que≈øtion, Sir, Is the Pri≈øoner at the Bar a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Yes, I have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs twenty times in his Habit.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he give the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Yes, I ≈øaw him give the Sacrament to ≈øeveral, and he did hear Confe≈ø≈øions; he had a great many People about him.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Two or three years ago.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: At the Spani≈øh Emba≈ø≈øadors, at Wild-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, here is Sir William Waller, that took him with his Ve≈øtments, and all his Trinkets.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Come, What ≈øay you, Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sir Will. Waller.
sp.p: That Morning I took him, as ≈øoon as I came into the Room, I asked him his Name? He told me his Name was Ru≈ø≈øel; I asked him, If ever he went by any other Name? He deny'd it for ≈øome time, but looking among≈øt ≈øome of his Papers, I found ≈øome Letters, directed to him by the Name of Napper. And then he did confe≈øs his Name was William Ru≈ø≈øel Napper. Searching among his Clothes, I found ≈øome Religious Habits; I asked him, If they were his? and he confe≈ø≈øed and owned them to be his.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: It was in my cu≈øtody; it was none of mine.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why did you ≈øay ≈øo then?

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: I kept it for another.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you told him it was your own: VVhat ≈øay you to that?

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: I do not remember that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: VVell, he ≈øwears it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here are two po≈øitive VVitne≈ø≈øes again≈øt you, what ≈øay you to it? VVhat ≈øay you to his ≈øaying, He hath heard you ≈øay Ma≈øs twenty times?

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: VVhat ≈øay you to the ≈øaying Ma≈øs at the time Dr. Oates ≈øpeaks of?

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: I believe he is mi≈øtaken, as to the time and year. I was entred into the Hou≈øe in‚Äî78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: Then you think it was at another time?

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: He could not hear me at that time, for I was then in the Country.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any thing to ≈øay? It ≈øhall be allow'd you, it was at another time, but it ≈øeems 'tis true. Look you, Gentlemen, you have a very plain bu≈øine≈øs of it; here are two VVitne≈ø≈øes that Swear they ≈øaw him give Ab≈øolution, deliver the Sacrament, and heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs, and one ≈øay twenty times. And Sir William Waller, who ≈øays, That he confe≈ø≈øed the Prie≈øts Habit to be his own.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: Con≈øider my Circum≈øtances, and give me a little time; I have not had any time to get my Friends near me, or to prepare my ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I do not ≈øee any good time would do you. I think the be≈øt u≈øe you can make of your time, is to repent.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, the Court here is pe≈øtred with Papi≈øts; here are a great many about here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If they be VVitne≈ø≈øes we can't keep them out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: Some of them may be VVitne≈ø≈øes, but all are not; and if they be, they come to catch advantages.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Dolben.
sp.p: I don't under≈øtand why they ≈øhould be turned out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Let them alone: be at quiet.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, they will revile us, That they had not an open and a fair Hearing: we won't have it ≈øaid, that we do any thing in Hugger-mugger; what we do is done openly and hone≈øtly.

sp.speaker: Cl. Cr.
sp.p: Set Charles Parris, ali√†s Parry, to the Bar. Hold up thy hand. You that are Sworn, &c.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury. The Offence for which the Pri≈øoner at the Bar ≈øtands Indicted, is High Trea≈øon, the ≈øame Offence for which the re≈øt have been Indicted‚Äî

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then call your VVitne≈ø≈øes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode. Dr. Oates, and Mr. Prance.
sp.p: (VVho were Sworn.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat can you ≈øay again≈øt the Pri≈øoner, as to his being a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he is a reputed Prie≈øt, and hath ≈øaid Ma≈øs ≈øeveral times. I have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs at Wild-hou≈øe, not in the publick Chappel, but in another Room.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhere do you ≈øay?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Once at Wild-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhere el≈øe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: At Mr. Pa≈øton's.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhen was this, VVinter or Summer?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: VVithin the compa≈øs of a Year, reckoning‚Äî77 and‚Äî78. It was of a Saturday one time, and twice at Mr. Pa≈øton's, and once or twice, I can't tell which, at the other place.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And in the Prie≈øts Habit?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, in the Prie≈øts Habit.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And did you ≈øee him Con≈øecrate the Ho≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And give the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: My Lord, as to that he ≈øpeaks of Seventy ≈øeven or Seven eight, what Month of Seventy eight, I de≈øire to know?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cannot confine my ≈øelf to a Month; I knew him to be a Prie≈øt, but I was little acquainted with him, but he was a reputed Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Jones.
sp.p: But you are ≈øure this is the man?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, this is the man.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: Am I the man? What is my Name?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: You went by the name of John≈øon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you never go by that name of John≈øon?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: No, my Lord, but by this name of Parry: Parry is my name, and by that name I went, a ‚Ä¢ d never by any other name than Parry, whatever he ≈øays.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, by that ≈øame name you are indicted, and you are the man that he ≈øaw.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Will you ask him ever a Que≈øtion?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I have askt him already what I would ask him.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: Then ≈øet up Mr. Prance.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you ≈øay as to Mr. Parry?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: My Lord, I know he is a Prie≈øt; I have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs at the Venetian Emba≈ø≈øadors, and at Mr. Pa≈øtons too.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Once at Pa≈øton's, and two or three times at the Venetian Emba≈ø≈øadors.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And you ≈øaw him give the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In his Habit?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: At what time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: I believe it might be half a year before the Plot. And I know you by another Circum≈øtance. You brought a Chalice to my Hou≈øe, and it was whole, and you broke it, and told me, I mu≈øt not touch it till it was broke, and ≈øo you defaced it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That was an holy Ve≈ø≈øel, was it not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Yes, and he told me I mu≈øt not touch it till it was broken in pieces.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you had not been a Prie≈øt, he had been as holy as you, and he might have touch'd it as well as you.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: His breaking was to de≈øecrate it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: He bought ≈øome Oyl Boxes of me about that time.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I do not know this man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: You were ≈øeveral times with me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why have you forgot the Chalice you brought to his Hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I have no rea≈øon to forget my ≈øelf, for I never did any ≈øuch thing: for I never brought nor ≈øold to him any Chalice or any ≈øuch thing, and be≈øides, ≈øuppo≈øe I had‚Äî

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, there is no great ≈øtre≈øs laid upon that, but to ≈øhew you, that he knows you, he did not mi≈øtake the man. The ≈øtre≈øs of the Evidence lies, that he heard you ≈øay Ma≈øs at the Venetian Emba≈ø≈øadors, and at Pa≈øtons. And then Dr. Oates ≈øpeaks of Wilde-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I had Order to ≈øend for two Witne≈ø≈øes out of Monmouth≈øhire‚Äî

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here is proof enough.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: What have you to ≈øay for your ≈øelf?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I have this to ≈øay, and can ≈øhew it evidently, that is, I have Witne≈ø≈øes to prove, that I never was at Wildhou≈øe to Officiate in the year 77 and 78 before the Plot. And for this 6 or 7 Moneths that Mr. Prance does alleadge I was in London, I was in the Country.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: Six or Seven Moneths before the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He did not confine him≈øelf preci≈øely to any Six or Seven Moneths.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: My Lord, I de≈øired him to fix upon a moneth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: He cannot do it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If he can, let him; We will Ask him the Que≈øtion. When was it that you ≈øaw him do thus?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: My Lord, I am not certain what time it was, but about two, or two years and an half ago, I am not certain, 'tis impo≈ø≈øible for me to remember it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: You mu≈øt take him in what he ≈øays, this he is ≈øure of, he did hear you ≈øay Ma≈øs, and give the Sacrament, but as to the time, he believes it to be about this time, but he is not po≈øitive, nor can be in it.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: He only believes it now, becau≈øe he knows I have Witne≈ø≈øes for that time. He hath Sworn it po≈øitively, it was ≈øix or ≈øeven moneths before the Plot, and I have Witne≈ø≈øes to produce, can prove, how long before the Plot I was in the Country.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call your Witne≈ø≈øes.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: Call Lan≈øcroon and Jacob.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long was it before the Plot, as near as you can, tell the time Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I have heard ≈øo many Prie≈øts, that I cannot po≈ø≈øible give an account of the day.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I de≈øire to know of Mr. Oates who was Emba≈ø≈øador at Wildhou≈øe at that time when he ≈øayes he heard me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Were you never at Pa≈øton's?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Nor at the Venetian Re≈øidents?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Mr. Parry was not, but Mr. John≈øon was.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I know not Mr. John≈øon, my name is Parry.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: I mean Mr. John≈øon, alias Parry.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Prance, you are ≈øure that is the man?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Yes; And I heard him confe≈øs him≈øelf to be a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: And this is the man that brought the Chalice to you?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why did you never go with a Chalice to this man, and break it?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: My Lord, I never bought any thing of him, nor ≈øold any thing to him, nor had any conver≈øe with him.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: I do never wonder at their denying any thing, I would feign know whether he would not deny the Sun ≈øhines now or no?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: And then for the Private Room, What Room of the Hou≈øe was it?

sp.speaker: Prance.
sp.p: I took him up in the middle of Cheap≈øide, and therefore I mu≈øt ≈øure know him.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: He did not know me, but only took me on ≈øu≈øpition at Random, becau≈øe I was in the Company of a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What would you have this man Asked?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: About the year 77 and 78, wherein Mr. Oates alleadges he heard me, let them An≈øwer to that, how long I was at Wind≈øor? And whether I did not dwell con≈øtantly there?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, you hear the Que≈øtion. How long was he at Wind≈øor?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: From what time do you Ask?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: Nay, you mu≈øt not be lead into an An≈øwer. How long was he at Wind≈øor?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: From Chri≈øtma≈øs 77, to Alhallantide 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Ellys.
sp.p: And was he never at London all that time?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: How can you tell that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Atkyns.
sp.p: Was he alwayes in your fight all the time?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: Yes, he was there always.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Atkyns.
sp.p: Were you there always your ≈øelf?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: A Painter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And was you and he always together at that time?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What in a Room?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Can you affirm, that for a Twelve moneth together, you ≈øaw him every day?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: How many years ago do you ≈øpeak of?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: From 77 to 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: I don't Ask you that, but how many years ago 'tis?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came he down to Wind≈øor?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: Chri≈øtma≈øs (77.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The Te≈øtimony of Mr. Oates goes to November, and he ≈øpeaks of Christma≈øs following.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: How many years ago was it, I Ask?

sp.speaker: Lan≈øcroon.
sp.p: A year ago la≈øt Chri≈øtma≈øs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: That is 78 and 79.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Pemberton.
sp.p: Your Witne≈øs is under≈øtood, Mr. Parry.

div.p: Then ≈øtood up the other Witne≈øs Jacob.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ≈øay you about Mr. Parry's being at Wind≈øor?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: He was a Gentleman that came along with me in the Coach to Wind≈øor.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Before Chri≈øtma≈øs (77.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long before?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Ten days. He came there to take the Air for his health, he was not well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long ≈øtaid he there?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: He ≈øtaid at Wind≈øor till Alhallantide after, he ≈øtaid there a year.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee him there every day of that year?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, what rea≈øon had you to ≈øee him every day?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: He dined every day at our hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Your hou≈øe? What hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: The Painters.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Dolben.
sp.p: However, that is but from Chri≈øtma≈øs, and he ≈øpeaks of November before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he Dine there all that time?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he never keep a Fa≈øt in all that time?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he dine a Wedne≈ødays and Fridays?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he dine there every Friday con≈øtantly?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: There was one Good Friday in that time.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Pray Ask this Witne≈øs if he never heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Dolben.
sp.p: Then he mu≈øt be Sworn, and may be he will deny it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he Dine of A≈øhwedne≈øday, and Good Friday?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So, he ≈øayes you eat of Good-Friday and A≈øhwedne≈øday, the Pope ≈øhall know it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: What ≈øay you? Did he eat Fle≈øh upon tho≈øe days?

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yes, he did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You can tell what he did eat, can you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Did he eat Beaf or Mutton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Dolben.
sp.p: Go, you talk like an idle Boy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He tells you, that you eat meat too, that is more:

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: My Lord, we eat Fi≈øh, and ≈øuch things all Catholicks do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: Ay the Prie≈øts do, but their Pupils do not, they will not allow it to them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, have you done, have you any more witne≈ø≈øes?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: My Lord, I would ask Mr. Oats, and de≈øire he would an≈øwer me to it, what he did depo≈øe again≈øt me before my Lord of Shaftsbury, and the Committee of Lords, concerning one Mr. Collins, that I heard his Confe≈ø≈øion at my Lord Amba≈ø≈øadors, now I have it to ≈øhew, that I did not Officiate there, nor frequent the Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who is it that will prove you did not come to the hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: The Venetian Amba≈ø≈øadors Servants.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I do not under≈øtand what you mean.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I am to ask of Mr. Oats, and I de≈øire he ≈øhould an≈øwer to it, What he did depo≈øe before my Lord Shaftsbury and the Committee of Lords, touching Mr. Collins.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He cannot remember it may be.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: You mu≈øt not ask ≈øuch que≈øtions as the≈øe are, it does not refer to this matter.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: He did give in that I heard Mr. Collins's Confe≈ø≈øion, I ask why he does not give it in now?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is a forreign matter, what have we to do with it now?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: If you will prove any thing again≈øt him, you may, but you may not ask ≈øuch que≈øtions as that.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I have proved that I was in 1677, and 1678. in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: They tell us of Ten days before Chri≈øtmas, and Mr. Oates ≈øpeaks of November.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you Gentlemen of the Jury, here are two witne≈ø≈øes again≈øt him, Mr. Oates and Mr. Prance.‚Äî

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: My Lord, I have one thing I de≈øire to be taken notice of, that is, this Letter of the Amba≈ø≈øadors, who upon the examination of all his Family does te≈øtify and declare, that I did never Officiate in any re≈øpect in his Family.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It cannot be read.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pember.
sp.p: It is not any Evidence.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: How ≈øhall I clear my ≈øelf, if the te≈øtimony of the Amba≈ø≈øador, and his whole Family be not admitted?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: 'Tis a hard thing for you to clear your ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why don't you bring them hither as your Witne≈ø≈øes?

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: Where is my Lord Amba≈ø≈øador, why does not he come hither?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: He hath left the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: Then you may boldly ≈øay any thing of him, and we cann't di≈øprove you.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is all his Family gone with him?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: There is but one remaining, I think he's here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call him.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: Mon≈øieur Rivier. (who appeared and ≈øtood up)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: Do you know this Hand, Sir?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It mu≈øt not be read if he do.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: He is one of the Servants to my Lord Egmont, and he lived in the Hou≈øe, and he knows‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Ask him any que≈øtion, but don't tell him what he knows

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why don't you ask him ≈øome que≈øtions? why, you have not Catechi≈øms in your Church, you don't know how to ask que≈øtions.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: Ask him whether he ever heard me ≈øay Ma≈øs at my Lord Amba≈ø≈øadors Hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It's to no purpo≈øe if he did not, here are ≈øome have.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: Then my Lord, he knows that there was a ≈øtrict examination at Wild-hou≈øe by my Lords Orders, whether I did frequent the hou≈øe, and it was reported by them all I did not, and they mu≈øt know if ever I did officiate there, for there is none admitted to ≈øay Ma≈øs there, but by Order.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Look you Sir, do you know that Mr. Parry ever ≈øaid Ma≈øs at Wild-hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: Rivier.
sp.p: No my Lord, I do not know it.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: It was in a private Room, Dr. Oates ≈øayes.

sp.speaker: Rivier.
sp.p: I never ≈øaw him there.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: If you ask an hundred here, they would ≈øay the ≈øame thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Come, when matters are plain 'tis in vain to contend; here is the bu≈øine≈øs Gentlemen, here are Mr. Oates and Mr. Prance, two witne≈ø≈øes again≈øt Mr. Parry, Mr. Oates ≈øays, he hath heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs one time at one place, and twice or thrice at another. Mr. Prance hath heard him often, and Mr. Prance does tell you plainly, that he cannot err, that he is not mi≈øtaken in the man, for he came to his hou≈øe with a Chalice, and broke it there, and he knew him ≈øo well, that meeting him by chance, he took him up in the ≈øtreets; ≈øo if you believe them, they ≈øwear it po≈øitively, and you mu≈øt find it ≈øo.

div.p: Then the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice went away.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set Henry Starkey to the Bar. Hold up thy hand, &c.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury. Henry Starkey ≈øtands Indicted for the like offence with the other pri≈øoners; that he having received Orders from the See of Rome, came into England, and this is High Trea≈øon; to this he hath pleaded Not Guilty, we will prove it upon him. Sweat Doctor Oates and Mr. Prance. (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: Pray Sir will you tell my Lord and the Gentlemen of the Jury, what you do know of this Starkeys being a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, Mr. Starkey is a Prie≈øt, and I once heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs at Mr. Pa≈øton's.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: When was that? How long was it agoe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: It is about three years agoe.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: Did he give the Sacrament then, or at any other time?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: None received but him≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Was he in Prie≈øts Habit?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Did he receive the Sacrament, and con≈øecrate the Ho≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, in both kinds.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: Will you ask him any que≈øtions?

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: He tells me of the Prie≈øts Habits, What are they Sir?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p:
Under it he was in a Secular Habit, but fir≈øt he had a thing about his Neck, a piece of Linnen, I have forgot what they
call it, and over that he had a Surplice girt about him, and a Stole about his Neck over that.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: Dr. Oates, if you be ≈øo, for I do not know you, a Prie≈øts Habit is a Ca≈ø≈øock and a Cloak, the Ornaments of a Prie≈øt are not a Surplice, but an‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: You are well skill'd in it I ≈øee.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: And how did you know that I ≈øaid Ma≈øs? Did you know that I took Orders? for if I took no Orders, it was no Ma≈øs; for it is the Prie≈øt makes the Ma≈øs, and not the Ma≈øs the Prie≈øt; and then if I was no Prie≈øt, it could be no Ma≈øs.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: That is a pretty Argument indeed; Do any but Prie≈øts ≈øay Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: I can bring in≈øtance of a Gentleman in this Town, a private Lay-man, who did ≈øay Ma≈øs about this Town, and he was a Prote≈øtant, and at la≈øt he ≈øtole the Chalice.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: He did well, did he not?

sp.speaker: L. C. B.
sp.p: 'Tis a great Evidence this arguing of yours, if he did not ≈øwear it, that you are a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: I wonder that this Gentleman ≈øhould ≈øo well remember me, I don't know him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Do you think you know every one that hath ≈øeen you at Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: Set up Mr. Prance. What ≈øay you Sir to this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: My Lord, I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs at my Lady Somer≈øets, and at Mr. Pa≈øtons.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: As I hope for mercy from Almighty God, I was never there in all my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: More than that, I heard him confe≈øs him≈øelf a Prie≈øt to one Mr. Duncomb.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: What is that he ≈øayes?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Did you know one Mr. Duncomb that is dead?

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: Yes, he was a Schoolma≈øter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Well, I heard you ≈øay Ma≈øs at his Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: I'll tell you what then, it was with a Pot of Ale, and at 3 or 4 a clock in the afternoon, for that was the only time I was there.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I have heard him ≈øay, he ≈øaid Ma≈øs in the Kings Army.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: He tels you, he heard you ≈øay, that you did often in the Kings Army ≈øay Ma≈øs.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: You never heard me ≈øay ≈øo in your life, for I never did. But pray my Lord give me leave to ≈øpeak: I appeared for the King, when he had but 500 men in appearance for him. I am but a younger Brother, an E≈øquires 2d Brother; I ≈øpent in the King's ≈øervice above 5000l. which I got my ≈øelf, and bled for it before I had it. I ≈øpent my Annuity of Seven≈øcore pound a year for the King, I lo≈øt my Leg for him, and ≈øpent my E≈øtate to that Degree, that that day when I receiv'd the ≈øentence of Bani≈øhment, I had but Two half Crowns left.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Mr. Starkey, You may urge this to the King, for his Mercy and Clemency, 'tis nothing to the point here before the Jury to be Tryed. What≈øoever you have merited by your ≈øervices, you mu≈øt apply your ≈øelf to the King for his mercy, it is nothing here.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p:
Pray my Lord, give me leave to add one thing more, I
did di≈øcover to the King a Plot de≈øigned again≈øt His Per≈øon, State, and Government, and I ≈øuffer to this day for it.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: You may be a Prie≈øt for all that.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: But my Lord, by the Civil Law it is a conclu≈øion, that although a man be a Traitor, and in the ≈øame Plot, he is to be indemnified for di≈øcovering the Con≈øpiracy again≈øt his Prince, much more for di≈øcovering another.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: We have nothing to do with that here, but whether you are a Prie≈øt or not.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: That I mu≈øt leave to the proof.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Well then, I'll tell you Gentlemen, this per≈øon is Indicted for being a Prie≈øt and coming into England. For the point of his being a Prie≈øt you have heard two witne≈ø≈øes depo≈øe; and they both tell you, that they have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs, as great an evidence of it as can be, for none ≈øay Ma≈øs but Prie≈øts. Dr. Oates tels you at Mr. Pa≈øton's. Mr. Prance ≈øays at Mr. Pa≈øton's, at my Lady Somer≈øets, and one Mr. Duncombs. If you believe this, you mu≈øt find him guilty.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: And they ≈øpeak too, to his receiving the Sacraments in both kinds.

sp.speaker: Stark.
sp.p: If I was there, ≈øure there was ≈øome body el≈øe be≈øides my ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cu.
sp.p: Set Alexan. Lum≈øden to the Bar. Hold up thy Hand, &c. Your Charge is to enquire of him as of your fir≈øt Pri≈øoner, and hear your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury, Alexander Lum≈øden the pri≈øoner at the Bar, ≈øtands Indicted for High Trea≈øon, for that he being a Prie≈øt, and receiving Orders from Rome, did come here into England, and abide contrary to the Statute.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: Swear Dr. Oates, Mr. Dugdale, and Mr. Prance, (which was done)

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Come Dr. Oates, What ≈øay you to this man?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs, he is a Dominican Fryer as I remember. I heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs 20 times at Wild-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: And Con≈øecrate the Ho≈øt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, and I reciv'd the Sacrament from him.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: And ≈øee him take Confe≈ø≈øion?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Will you ask him any que≈øtions?

sp.speaker: Lum≈øden.
sp.p: What time was this, if it plea≈øe you Sir?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: That Summer that was before the Plot broke out. Mr. Lum≈øden knows me well enough.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Do you not know him?

sp.speaker: Lum≈øden.
sp.p: Truly I do not know that ever I ≈øaw him, or conver≈øed with him in my life.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: What ≈øay you Mr. Dugdale?

sp.speaker: Dugdale.
sp.p: My Lord, I was at Whitehal that day Mr. Lum≈øden was taken; and by the importunity of ≈øome friends I did goe to him, but I did not know him, but by di≈øcour≈øe he did confe≈øs him≈øelf a Prie≈øt; I asked him if he was a Franci≈øcan, he ≈øaid he was a Dominican.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: He is Procurator-General of the Kingdom of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: They have ≈øuch a parcel of people, and ≈øuch names for them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: Mr. Prance, what do you know of Lum≈øden's being a Prie≈øt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: I know he is a Prie≈øt, and have heard him ≈øay Ma≈øs ≈øeveral times at Wild-Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Was he there in the Habit?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Yes, and con≈øecrated the Ho≈øt.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: How long ≈øince?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Two years ≈øince, I heard him 20 times.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Do you know what Countreyman he is?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: An Iri≈øh man I think.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: No, he is a Scotchman, he will not deny it.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: What Countreyman are you?

sp.speaker: Lum≈øden.
sp.p: A Scotchman.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: Of what part of Scotland?

sp.speaker: Lum≈øden.
sp.p: Aberdeen.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Were you born there?

sp.speaker: Lum≈øden.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: You have no more to ≈øay, have you?

sp.speaker: Lum≈ød.
sp.p: My Lord, I am not here I think, to be my own Accu≈øer, I humbly conceive ≈øo, and what≈øoever is again≈øt me, mu≈øt be proved, not ≈øimply a≈ø≈øerted. They ought to give Proofs and Rea≈øons; but ≈øo it is, it is but a ≈øimple a≈ø≈øertion what they ≈øay. I de≈øire they may prove it.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: No, they need not; it is ≈øufficient if they prove it by ≈øuch Circum≈øtances that the Jury are ≈øatisfied and convinced that it is true. But it is not to be looked for, that no proof ≈øhould be given again≈øt the Prie≈øt, but by them that ≈øaw him receive Orders.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: 'Tis impo≈ø≈øible almo≈øt to prove that.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: But if they prove the Circum≈øtances, that you have executed the Office of a Prie≈øt by ≈øaying Ma≈øs, which none does but a Prie≈øt, 'tis enough to guide them in their Verdict.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Ellis.
sp.p: And they have proved that which is next to a po≈øitive A≈ø≈øertion.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: That need not be.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Ellis.
sp.p: But let us not le≈ø≈øen our proof neither.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: You mu≈øt con≈øider that the proof is certain, for they have ≈øworn an a≈ø≈øertive po≈øitive thing, which thing is enough to a Jury to prove you a Prie≈øt, becau≈øe none others but Prie≈øts may do ≈øuch things in your Church as you have done. Therefore it is a good Argument and Evidence, to conclude you a Prie≈øt, from this Evidence that hath been given.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I have heard him own him≈øelf a Prie≈øt 20 times.

sp.speaker: Lum≈øden.
sp.p: The exerci≈øe of the Prie≈øtly Function is but a penalty of 200 Marks.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Ay, that is, if the King will go no higher. But you are pro≈øecuted upon another Law.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Ellis.
sp.p: 'Tis Evidence, and a great Evidence, that which hath been given, for we mu≈øt go according to the nature of the thing. 'Tis impo≈ø≈øible the Act of Parliament ≈øhould be put in execution, if they mu≈øt prove they received Orders from the See of Rome. But when they have proved tho≈øe things done by any man, which none ought to do but a Prie≈øt; it hath been in all times allowed to be a ≈øpecial Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: 'Tis a plain and ≈øufficient Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Ellis.
sp.p: But if there were any need of it, and you would have any more, he hath confe≈ø≈øed upon the que≈øtion asked him, whether he was a Franci≈øcan, no, he was a Dominican.

sp.speaker: L. C. Bar.
sp.p: Have you done? Then Gentlemen of the Jury, you mu≈øt not at this time of the day be in≈ønared by that Argument, that there mu≈øt be a po≈øitive proof of this Reception of Orders from the Church of Rome, becau≈øe it hath been all along accounted, and is an undoubted proof for your ≈øatisfaction, if it appear he hath exerci≈øed the Offices of the Function; tho≈øe Offices that are not done but by Prie≈øts. Now this hath been proved by two witne≈ø≈øes, and by the confe≈ø≈øion of the Prie≈øt him≈øelf to Dr. Oates and Mr. Dugdale. So I mu≈øt leave it upon the point of Fact to you, whether it be not ≈øufficient proof. But this Ca≈øe will differ from all the re≈øt, and the Court is very tender in the ca≈øe of Life, that it ≈øhould be without all que≈øtion what is determined; therefore as to your enquiry for him, it mu≈øt go only whether he be a Prie≈øt or no, for the others, you mu≈øt con≈øider them as Engli≈øhmen, and enquire of them as ≈øuch; he is a Scotchman, as he ≈øays, and they ≈øay ≈øo too. Now then there are ≈øome words in this Statute, whereupon the Court hath conceived a doubt, whether his Ca≈øe comes within them, which are the words about the Kings Dominions, which now are far more enlarged than were tho≈øe of the Queen when the Statute was made: If then you find him a Prie≈øt, you mu≈øt find the other matter ≈øpecially.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Ellis.
sp.p: Look you Gentlemen, we are to be of Coun≈øel for the Pri≈øoner, and it being matter of Law, we ≈øhall take time to advi≈øe upon it before we give our opinions in it; but for the matter of Fact, I doubt not but you will find that he is a Prie≈øt; and then the other matters, that he was born at Aberdeen in Scotland; and the other matters you may find ≈øpecially, there needs no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: Swear an Officer to keep the Jury.

div.p: Who after the rece≈øs of a quarter of an hour, returned into the Court, and having an≈øwered to their Names, and appointed their Foreman to give in their Verdict, he delivered it thus.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Lionel Ander≈øon alias Mun≈øon, hold up thy hand, look upon the Pri≈øoner, how ≈øay you, is he guilty of the High Trea≈øon, whereof he ≈øtands Indicted, or not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: James Corker, hold up thy hand. How ≈øay you, is he guilty, &c.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Is William Mar≈øhal guilty, &c.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Is William Ru≈ø≈øel alias Napper guilty, &c.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Is Charles Parry guilty, &c.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Is Henry Starkey guilty, &c.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Crown.
sp.p: Alexander Lum≈øden, hold up thy hand. Look upon the Pri≈øoner, How ≈øay you, Is he Guilty of the High-Trea≈øon whereof he ≈øtands Indicted, or Not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: We find he is Guilty of being a Prie≈øt, and born at Abberdeen in Scotland.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju≈øtice Ellys.
sp.p: Read the Notes to them.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Crown.
sp.p: You find that Alexander Lum≈øden is a Scotchman, of 58 years of age, born at Abberdeen in the Kingdom of Scotland, being then under the Dominions of King Charles the Fir≈øt, and now under the Dominions of our pre≈øent Sovereign, and in the Reign of the ≈øaid King Charles the Fir≈øt; and that at the time in the Indictment mentioned, he was a Prie≈øt in Holy Orders, by Authority derived from the See of Rome, prout in the Indictment. And that he came and was remaining in England, prout in the Indictmment. But whether upon the whole matter he be Guilty of High-Trea≈øon within this Law or not, you do not know, and crave the Opinion of the Court.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Crown.
sp.p: Then hearken to your Verdict, as the Court hath Recorded it; You ≈øay, &c.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Call for the Executioner.
Then the Judges went off from the Bench, and the Court proceeded to Judgment.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Crown.
sp.p: Set Lionel Ander≈øon, alias Mun≈øon to the Bar. Lionel Ander≈øon, alias Mun≈øon, Thou ≈øtande≈øt Convicted of High-Trea≈øon, What can≈øt thou ≈øay for thy ≈øelf, why Judgment ≈øhould not pa≈øs upon thee to Die according to the Law?

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I can ≈øay this, That I would have gone out of England, but the King kept me here, telling me, He had need of my Service; and, I had a Protection from the Council-Board. The Bi≈øhop of London, when I was taken fir≈øt, ≈øent a Letter to Sir Clement Armiger, that neither I, nor my Books, ≈øhould be medled with; that I had written for the King and the Government, for which I was Excommunicated at Rome. And when I was taken, and in Cu≈øtody of ≈øome of the Hor≈øe-Guard, the Duke of Monmouth ≈øent to have me freed again. I beg'd of the King, that I might go; ≈øaid I, I wont expo≈øe the King to the wor≈øt of Rebels: but he told me, That I ≈øhould ≈øtay in England; and Mr. Peter Wel≈øh and I had Orders from the Council, he one, and I another, to ≈øtay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: For that matter you may be a≈ø≈øured, I promi≈øe it you faithfully, and publickly, that I will acquaint the King with what you ≈øay.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: For this Court hath nothing to do with that, the King is the proper Judge of that matter, to determine his own plea≈øure, as he thinks fit: Tye him up

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p:
Sir, I had no notice of my Tryal, but this morning. I ≈øent to my Lord Bridgewater, to know when I ≈øhould be Tryed, he told me, I ≈øhould have Ten dayes notice of it. Now I have Witne≈ø≈øes to di≈øprove Mr. Prance's Te≈øtimony: for Mr. Oates, I own
he hath heard me ≈øay Ma≈øs; but for Mr. Bedloes Te≈øtimony, as I hope to ≈øee the face of Almighty God, I know him not. When I was taken, ≈øaid he to me, Mr. Ander≈øon, Let me ≈øee your Protection, and I ≈øhewed it him; You have two Names, ≈øaid he, I do not know whether it be you or no. And then be≈øides, the≈øe are not legal Witne≈ø≈øes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Nay, that mu≈øt not be allowed you to ≈øay. You have been fairly heard, and tryed. They were upon their Oaths, and the Jury, Twelve Men, upon their Oaths, without any Exception made to them; they have Convicted you; therefore this is to Calumniate the Proceedings of the Court.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I tell you this more; they are not the Kings Evidence properly, for they Swear for them≈øelves, upon the accompt of Benefit, if any Prie≈øt be Convicted, they are to have ≈øo much Mony.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: The Court heard the Evidence that was given, and if you will have it of the Court, the Court does really believe them, and ≈øo did the Jury too.

sp.speaker: Ander≈øon.
sp.p: I am ≈øatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Tye him up then.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Crown.
sp.p: James Corker, hold up thy Hand. You ≈øtand Convicted of High-Trea≈øon, What can you ≈øay for your ≈øelf, &c.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: Nothing, but that I refer my ≈øelf to God my Ju≈øt Judge and Saviour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Tye him up.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Crown.
sp.p: William Mar≈øhall, hold up thy hand, thou art in the ≈øame Condition, What ≈øay'≈øt thou for thy ≈øelf?

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: I have very little more to ≈øay, then what I have ≈øaid already. I thought the Law had not allowed any Man to have been Condemned upon the Te≈øtimony of one Witne≈øs, but required two. Now there was but one po≈øitive Witne≈øs again≈øt me, the re≈øt only ≈øaid, I had confe≈ø≈øed my ≈øelf to be a Prie≈øt. Two of them did Swear, they heard me confe≈øs it at my other Tryal: If it had been at this Tryal, it had been another thing, and there had been ≈øome validity in the proof; but, to ≈øay, they heard me Confe≈øs it at another time, I humbly conceive, according to the Law, bears no force. I have this further to add, His Maje≈øty, ≈øome years ago, put forth a Declaration under the Broad-Seal, for a To ‚Ä¢ leration of Religion, and Liberty of Con≈øcience, whereby the Roman Catholicks had the u≈øe of their Religion in their private Hou≈øes. Now, I have been informed, that according to Law, what≈øoever is put forth under the Broad-Seal, mu≈øt be recalled by ≈øomething under the Broad-Seal, or it remains in force, which was never done as to this Declaration, and then I lye under the Protection of that Declaration.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: As for the fir≈øt part, 'tis plain, to the ≈øatisfaction of every body, that there hath been two Sufficient Witne≈ø≈øes, upon who≈øe Te≈øtimony you are Convicted. For whether you were asked the Que≈øtion or not, yet if you will ≈øay you are a Prie≈øt, that Confe≈ø≈øion of yours is Evidence again≈øt you, though you might po≈ø≈øibly ≈øay ≈øo without being Asked the Que≈øtion.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Is it credible I ≈øhould do ≈øo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Yes, the Jury believed it ≈øo.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: One of the Jury ≈øtood by and heard the Words.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: And now, becau≈øe I will put it out of all doubt, 'tis not the bu≈øine≈øs, nor the Duty of the Court to give any Evidence of any Fact that they know of their own knowledge, unle≈øs they will be Sworn for that purpo≈øe: for though they do know it in their own private Con≈øciences to be true, yet they are obliged to conceal their own knowledge, unle≈øs they will be Sworn as Witne≈ø≈øes. But now you are Convicted, I mu≈øt take the liberty to tell you, that at your la≈øt Tryal you did own your ≈øelf to be a Prie≈øt. And I mu≈øt put you in mind further of ≈øomething which you may very well remember, when I detained you after your Acquittal, and Recommitted you when Sir George Wakeman was di≈øcharged; I did then tell you, you having owned your ≈øelves to be Prie≈øts, I was bound to take notice of that Confe≈ø≈øion of yours, and therefore obliged to detain you. Such a Token as that is, may perhaps bring it to your Memory: but as it was hinted to you before, you are a Voluminous Talker, and abundance of things may drop out of your Mouth, that you don't con≈øider before they are pa≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: 'Tis for my life, and therefore I may be permitted to ≈øpeak ≈øure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: That is as to the fir≈øt point. And then as to the Kings Declaration, which was the other matter you in≈øi≈øted upon, I pre≈øume it does not ≈øtick with any body that knows the matter; but lea≈øt it ≈øhould, I would ≈øay this to it. 'Tis very well known in the fir≈øt place (I do not go now to determine the Law upon it, becau≈øe you know what Opinions and Judgment it received afterwards) yet this I will adventure to ≈øay, That it was never the intention of that Declaration that ever Prie≈øts ≈øhould come and re≈øide here, but it was only intended for tender Con≈øciences, as the very Letter of the Declaration it ≈øelf does ≈øhew, not to Countenance Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits, that have ca≈øt off all their Allegiance to the King, and endeavour both to de≈øtroy Him and His Government.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Pray Sir, Will you give me leave to ≈øpeak as to that. If ≈øo be the u≈øe of their Religion were permitted to Roman Catholicks, that Religion not being to be practi≈øed without Prie≈øts, it is to be ≈øuppo≈øed, that the Prie≈øts are permitted.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: But if a Man were to Argue with you now, in your own way, Pray are there not Prie≈øts in England, be≈øides tho≈øe Prie≈øts that were born here? You know, of your own Acquaintance, there are ≈øeveral Roman Catholick Prie≈øts, not Engli≈øhmen born, that are con≈øtantly here, who can perform the Offices.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Nay, I don't know that: But this I know, if they be not born in England, or have lived in England, ≈øo as to know the Tongue, Roman Catholicks will be little the better for them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Nay, I don't ≈øay much the better, but much the wor≈øe for their coming at them. And in ca≈øe they would only u≈øe the Engli≈øh truth, I pre≈øume they would not have ≈øo many Pro≈øelytes, but you Gull them with ≈øtuff they under≈øtand not.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p:
Pray Sir give me leave a little, I have one word more. For all matters of Trea≈øon, and Treacherous Con≈øpiracy, I was freed before in this Court; now I would ob≈øerve, what the be≈øt
Lawyers that ever were in England have ob≈øerved for me, That there is no Crime in Prie≈øthood it ≈øelf: for my Lord Coke in his Fifth Report 39. leaf, commenting largely upon the Statute of the twenty ≈øeventh of Eliz. and inlarging upon the ≈øence and meaning of that Statute, and calling to mind, who the men were that were formerly Executed by force of that Statute, and why, concludes thus. Hence it appears, that no man yet hath or can be Executed for his Function of Prie≈øthood, but becau≈øe there was annexed to the Prie≈øthood treacherous De≈øigns and treacherous Attempts. And the ≈øame Lawyer in the 3 d. In≈øtitutes, 22th. leaf, ≈øays, That in this Statute of the 27th. of Elizabeth, 'twas very wi≈øely and ju≈øtly done by the Statute-Makers, to provide that the Judges ≈øhould proceed in their Judgments upon that matter, only according to what is expre≈ø≈øed and ≈øpecified in that Statute. And tho≈øe words were a Sanctuary to the Judges, and put in to prevent the ≈øhedding of guiltle≈øs blood. Now if ≈øo be that ≈øo great a Lawyer, in a di≈øcour≈øe about Prie≈øthood and Treachery, does thence conclude, That Prie≈øthood as Prie≈øthood is no Crime, nor no Function belonging to it hath any Crime in it, well may I conclude ≈øo too. And indeed if it had, then a great part of the World would be Traitors, nay, it would bring in Chri≈øt him≈øelf who was a Prie≈øt, to be a Traytor too. Therefore Prie≈øthood as Prie≈øthood hath no Trea≈øon e≈ø≈øentially linkt to it. And when he ≈øays, that they mu≈øt proceed according to what is ≈øpecified, he does in the forementioned place ≈øhew, that it was not ≈øpecified at all, that any that were Executed, were for Prie≈øthood Executed. And I am accu≈øed of nothing el≈øe in the World, but bare Prie≈øthood as Prie≈øthood, without any De≈øign or Treachery joyned to it. And if according to Law Prie≈øthood be not liable to Condemnation, then I am not to be Condemned.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Now you have been heard.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and I thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p:
This long Speech of yours will ≈øignifie but little, when you con≈øider the Act of Parliament, upon which you are Indicted, ('tis true, ≈øet that Act of Parliament out of the Ca≈øe, and then to be a Prie≈øt is not High-Trea≈øon; nay, in ca≈øe a man be born out of the Kings Dominions, and be a Prie≈øt, and remain here, that is not High-Trea≈øon within this Statute, becau≈øe Prie≈øthood it ≈øelf does not make the Crime; (God forbid any one ≈øhould affirm it) but when all that is granted, when an Act of Parliament hath taken particularly notice of the great mi≈øchiefs and inconveniencies that have attended the Government, and the continual danger that the Supream head hath been in, by having Per≈øons which were born within the Kings Dominions, (as you were) to wave their Allegiance, and to acknowledge a Supremacy in any Foraign Prince or Prelate, as you all do, when you take Orders from the See of Rome; the Wi≈ødom of the Nation hath thought rea≈øonable that ≈øuch ≈øhould be adjudged Traitors. And this Act of Parliament upon which you ≈øtand Convicted, does plainly ≈øay, If any one born within the Kings Dominions will take Orders from the See of Rome, and ≈øhall after re≈øide here, he is guilty of High Trea≈øon. And this is
not only thought ≈øo by us that are here, but by all my Lords the Judges that were pre≈øent at your Tryal; for God forbid we ≈øhould Condemn you for any thing as High Trea≈øon, if you had not been within the Compa≈øs of the Act of Parliament. And what is Trea≈øon, the Act of Parliament particularly De≈øcribes, which all hath been proved upon you. And becau≈øe you are plea≈øed to ≈øpeak it to the Court, and lay it on the Con≈øciences of the Court, I Di≈øcharge my Con≈øcience, the Jury having Convicted you for High Trea≈øon, I am very ready to pa≈øs Judgment upon you according to the Law, and I will clear my Con≈øcience of that pre≈øently. Tie him up.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: William Ru≈ø≈øel, hold up thy Hand, Thou art in the ≈øame Ca≈øe, what can≈øt thou ≈øay for thy ≈øelf? &c.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: I can ≈øay this, my Lord, that in my Con≈øcience, I do not acknowledge my ≈øelf Guilty of what they accu≈øe me for, but I mu≈øt ≈øubmit to the Laws as they are made; but I do prote≈øt before Almighty God, and this whole Court, that I am innocent of all that is laid upon me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Why, what were you never at Wild-hou≈øe, and ≈øaid Ma≈øs there? I would feign hear, Whether you in the State and Condition you are in, (though your Je≈øuits have a Thou≈øand Tricks and Eva≈øions) have confidence enough to ≈øay you never were, nor ≈øaid Ma≈øs there?

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: I ought not to accu≈øe my ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: You are Convicted. But every thing that you ≈øay is but an Eva≈øion, and a Trick to catch and in≈ønare the ignorant, but people of any ≈øort of ≈øen≈øe, will not be gull'd ≈øo.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: For my Witne≈ø≈øes, you are my Witne≈øs, I have but one Witne≈øs upon that Bu≈øine≈øs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: The Jury have believed them.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: 'Tis po≈ø≈øible it may be ≈øo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis beyond po≈ø≈øible, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Ru≈ø≈øel.
sp.p: The Witne≈ø≈øes that have depo≈øed again≈øt me, for my part I know them not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: You have heard of Dr. Oates, Mr. Prance, and of Sir William Waller too. Tie him up.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Charles Parris alias Parry, hold up thy hand. You are in the ≈øame Condition, what have you to ≈øay?

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p:
What have I to ≈øay for my ≈øelf? I have this to ≈øay, That tho≈øe that did depo≈øe again≈øt me, did not ≈øay one word of Truth, I take God to witne≈øs for it. I am a Dead man by the Law, and I can Suffer, and I can prai≈øe God for his Holy will in that. I am as ready to Suffer the Law, as the Law is to inflict Suffering upon me, for it is for Gods glory; but I may pretend, and will pretend to, that I am not ≈øubject to the Law, in a≈ømuch as I have declared, that I am a Frenchman, and they are to prove that I am not. I was threatned by Sir William Waller when I was under the protection of an Emba≈ø≈øador; and notwith≈øtanding his protection, which was a violation of the Law of Nations, that one under his protection ≈øhould be ≈øo u≈øed, and that ≈ølighted as if it were nothing. But becau≈øe they did not regard it, I ≈øhewed it under his Hand and Seal; I alledged
in the next place, that I was a Frenchman; but becau≈øe I would not take my Oath that I was born a Frenchman, Sir W. Waller did threaten me with Irons; and therefore all that I ≈øaid was compelled and forced from me; then I ≈øaid I was a Monmouth-≈øhire man, becau≈øe my Father and my Mother were ≈øo, they are of that Countrey; but however it belonged to them to prove whether I was a Frenchman or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: No, I believe they cannot, would you have them prove you a Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I alledged my ≈øelf to be a Frenchman, but they would not believe me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Why, no body does. We believe you to be an Engli≈øhman.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: And if it plea≈øe you, they are to prove it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Well that is over now, Tie him up.

sp.speaker: Parry.
sp.p: I am not a Subject, and as not a Subject, am not under the penal Laws.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set Henry Starkey to the Bar. Henry Starkey, hold up thy Hand. Thou art in the ≈øame Condition with him that went la≈øt before thee, what can≈øt thou ≈øay for thy ≈øelf? &c.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: In the fir≈øt place Mr. Recorder, here is Mr. Prance hath Sworn a fal≈øe Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: I mu≈øt not hear that Mr. Starkey.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: Will you plea≈øe to hear me Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: I will give you all the freedom you can lawfully de≈øire in the world, but it mu≈øt be that which will con≈øi≈øt with my Duty, and the Reverence you owe the Court. You ≈øhall not revile the Kings Evidence as long as I am here, by the help of God.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: If that it were true, that I had ≈øaid Ma≈øs at my Lady Somer≈øets and Mr. Duncombs, yet it is not ≈øufficient to prove a man to be a Prie≈øt, for any man may take the Prie≈øts Garments, and do the Ceremony and the Office, becau≈øe there are thou≈øands that have ≈øuffered death for it that have not been Prie≈øts. And ≈øo, to do the≈øe Acts is not Evidence of being a Prie≈øt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Indeed I don't under≈øtand what makes a Romi≈øh Prie≈øt, nor do I de≈øire it.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: But you will give me the Letter of the Law.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: And the Jury hath found you a Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øour of the Law.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: The Letter of the Law is this. That if any one of the Queens Subjects, ≈øhall Tran≈øport him≈øelf beyond the Sea, and ≈øhall in a Seminary take Orders, by Authority derived from the See of Rome, and ≈øhall return into England, and ≈øhall not pre≈øent him≈øelf here to the Ordinary, or el≈øe to ≈øuch a certain number of Ju≈øtices of the Peace within ≈øuch a Term, but ≈øhall Seduce the Kings Leige people‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: No that is another Act.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p:
Then he ≈øhall be adjudged a Traitour. Now Mr. Recorder I come to this, as I told you before, I had di≈øcovered a Plot to the King that was de≈øigned again≈øt his Per≈øon, State, and Government, and did deliver into his hands Eleven Articles of Trea≈øon, which I had Writ with my own hands; and this he hath owned, and will‚ñ™ own So Mr.
Recorder, upon this, I was Threatned by tho≈øe that were parties to the Trea≈øon, That the King ≈øhould not be gone twenty four hours, but I ≈øhould be impri≈øoned. When the King went, what mu≈øt I do? Mu≈øt I ≈øtay there and hazard my life, or tru≈øt to the Kings Mercy? I was forced to come along with the King for Protection. I came to Whitehall, and the King ro≈øe up and gave me his hand to ki≈øs, and ≈øo did the Duke of York, and told me I was Welcome. I went to my Lord Chancellor Hyde, who, when he ≈øaw me, Embraced me in his Arms, and ≈øaid, Thou art welcome, I am glad to ≈øee thee in England. I had occa≈øion to ≈øpeak with the Bi≈øhop of London, Dr. Shelden about another Per≈øon, and when I came to him, he asked me, What is your Name? My Lord, ≈øaid I, my name is Starkey, with that he catches me fa≈øt by the hand, and when he had done that, he took me in his Arms, and told me, I am glad with all my heart to ≈øee you ≈øafe here in England. And Mr. Recorder, I do ≈øuffer to this day for the Service I have done the King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Mr. Starkey, I can only ≈øay this to you, I do promi≈øe you faithfully, as I promi≈øed the other Gentleman that went before, I'le tell the King what you alledge. He is the be≈øt able to give an accompt of it, and is the fitte≈øt Judge of his own Mercy. But I could recommend to you, Mr. Starkey, a thing that would be very acceptable, and then as far forth as tis mode≈øt for me to ≈øpeak, I am pretty well a≈ø≈øured, I might ≈øay, I could prevail for Mercy to you, That is, as you did Di≈øcover one Plot before, ≈øo you would Di≈øcover this Helli≈øh Plot that is now on foot.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: Mr. Recorder, I have wi≈øhed many times that one of the Commi≈ø≈øions that are ≈øaid to be delivered out, had been brought to me; for he that had delivered me a Commi≈ø≈øion, ≈øhould never have delivered a ≈øecond to any one el≈øe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Well, the King is the Fountain of Mercy, and he is the be≈øt Judge of the fit Objects of it. I will, as I ≈øaid, tell him what you ≈øay.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: If the King does not own what I told you, then count me the greate≈øt Knave that ever was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: You remain now under the Conviction of the Law, what Mercy the King, who is the Fountain of Mercy as well as of Ju≈øtice, will extend to you, is in his own power.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: Then Mr. Recorder, I have another thing to offer to you, and that is the Kings General and free Act of Pardon, made in the Twenty fifth year of his Reign, wherein he pardons all Trea≈øons, mispri≈øions of Trea≈øons, Felonies, and mispri≈øions of Felony, except what is excepted thereafter, and Prie≈øthood is not there excepted.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: You know very well, that the proof of your Trea≈øon hath been ≈øince the twenty fifth of this King, and within three years pa≈øt. I pre≈øume you do not think that the Kings Act of Pardon pardons all Trea≈øons pa≈øt and to come, as the Popes Bull does Sins. Tye him up then.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: But how ≈øhall I do then, when I am Lame? I want a Leg, and I mu≈øt u≈øe my Stick.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Then let him alone.

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: But I pray, good Mr. Recorder, will you be plea≈øed before you give Sentence upon me, to acquaint the King with what I have to ≈øay for my ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: No, I cannot do that, the Kings plea≈øure is to be known afterwards. Set Lum≈øden a≈øide, and ≈øet all the re≈øt to the Bar.

p.hi: Then Proclamation was made for Silence, Whil≈øt Judgment was a giving.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: YOU the Pri≈øoners at the Bar; You have been ≈øeverally Accu≈øed, Arraigned‚Äî

sp.speaker: Starkey.
sp.p: Mr. Recorder, May I ≈øpeak one word? I have pre≈øented this year, wherein at the 26th. of this Month I have been a Pri≈øoner, ≈øeveral Petitions by my Friends to the King, and de≈øired to be Tran≈øported; for my Age and infirmities and want of a Leg did not ≈øtand well with my being in England the≈øe trouble≈øom times. The King, I am told, hath promi≈øed I ≈øhould, but I ≈øee no fruits of tho≈øe Petitions. And pray con≈øider this, That I ≈øhould have been impri≈øoned if I ≈øtayed out of England, and now to be pro≈øecuted in England in this manner, and to be Drawn, Hang'd, and Quartered is very hard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p:
Whether it be true or not, God knows, I ≈øhall acquaint the King with it. It only remains with me to take notice of it for that purpo≈øe. And for my part I am ≈øorry with all my heart to ≈øee ≈øo many per≈øons brought to receive the Sentence of Death by my Mouth. But I mu≈øt ≈øay this, You your ≈øelves have been the occa≈øion of it, and therefore mu≈øt blame your ≈øelves for it. You have had the benefit of the be≈øt Laws, the Law of England, which gives every Subject the liberty to make a defence for him≈øelf, when ever he is accu≈øed of any Crime; He hath the liberty to hear the Witne≈ø≈øes what they ≈øay again≈øt him; to call any Witne≈ø≈øes for him, and to make defence for him≈øelf. And not only ≈øo, but he hath likewi≈øe Twelve Men upon their Oaths, that are his Peers, again≈øt whom he hath the liberty to make a Challenge without ≈øhewing any rea≈øon, to a certain number; and if it ≈øhall appear that any of them have the lea≈øt prejudice or malice again≈øt any Per≈øons that are to be Tried for their Lives, to a greater number. Such and ≈øo great is the benefit of the Laws of England, beyond all the Laws of any other Nation in the world. But all the≈øe forms having been pa≈ø≈øed, and a Jury of men, again≈øt whom you made no Exception, having found you Guilty of the Offences for which you were Indicted, there remains now nothing more with the Court, but to pa≈øs that Judgment of Death upon you, which the Law requires, and which is the bu≈øine≈øs that lies upon me now. But before I do that, for I know you may think it a pre≈øumption, or at lea≈øt
a needle≈øs and unnece≈ø≈øary thing for me to take upon me, and give any directions to you, the bu≈øine≈øs of who≈øe profe≈ø≈øion it hath been to give Precepts. However I think it is nece≈ø≈øary for the Satisfaction of ≈øome per≈øons that are here pre≈øent, that I ≈øhould give them ≈øome accompt, why I think this Law, and the putting it in execution at this time is not unrea≈øonable. For it is to be known, that every Subject of this Realm by his being born within the Dominions of the King, does owe an immediate Allegiance to the King, and is to take notice by the Law, that there is not any per≈øon hath any Superiority over him; for under God he is the Supream Head and Gonour. And if any per≈øon born within the Dominions of the King ≈øhall ≈øo far forget him≈øelf, and what he ows to the King by his Birth, and that Supremacy which he ≈øhould maintain with his Life and Fortune, as to acknowledge any other Forreign per≈øon to be Supream, and to have a power to Depo≈øe the King, and di≈øpo≈øe of his Dominions (as every one does, that takes Orders from the See of Rome) he cannot but be thought de≈øerving of the greate≈øt puni≈øhment. Wherefore the Wi≈ødom of our Nation, the Parliament, at the time when they made the Law, found that the Religion E≈øtabli≈øhed (that Religion which I hope in God will remain notwith≈øtanding all the Enemies it ever had or ≈øhall have) was invaded by ≈øuch Prie≈øts as you: they found the Life of the Queen at that time in great danger, by the attempts of tho≈øe Per≈øons whom they had made their Pro≈øelytes, into whom they had infu≈øed Principles, That it was no Crime for them to depo≈øe their Queen, ≈øince they had the Authority of their Pope to ju≈øtifie the Fact. And if once men can Preach ≈øuch Doctrine, and al≈øo but prevail with their Hearers to be of ≈øuch a Per≈øwa≈øion; if care were not taken, we ≈øhall ≈øoon ≈øee an end of all ≈øort of Government, and of our Religion too. But in as much as the≈øe Principles were not ≈øo vi≈øibly endeavoured to be put in practice till of late times, though you were not permitted, but connived at, yet that is no Rea≈øon but the occa≈øion of making the Law being revived, the Execution of the Law ≈øhould revive with it. I ≈øuppo≈øe it is not unknown to any of us, that there hath been an Helli≈øh Plot again≈øt the life of the King, and to de≈øtroy our Religion, I would to God I could ≈øay the Plot was at an end. For I mu≈øt ≈øay, Some of you, I fear, had too great a hand in it: and what a ≈øort of Mon≈øters were prevailed upon to compa≈øs the ≈øame, by you that are Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits, who have wrought them up to ≈øuch a belief, that Murther in this World is a certain way to Saint≈øhip in that which is to come. And though you ≈øeem to deny it, your practices are a proof of it beyond all contradiction, which is the rea≈øon that this Law, which was a good Law at the time of the making, and thought fit to be put in Execution then, though it hath ≈ølept ≈øome time ≈øince, ≈øhould now be put in Execution again≈øt you, who have occa≈øioned all tho≈øe mi≈øchiefs to this Nation in the≈øe latter times, which occa≈øioned the making of the Law. And one thing more I ≈øhould ≈øay to that man, who pretends to merit by the
good Services he hath done for the publick, that he ≈øhould injoin a man to ≈øcour his Kettle, as he calls it, to receive the Sacrament, and then give him a Di≈øpen≈øation to be Drunk, and make another ≈øo; to promote a damnable De≈øign, is ≈øuch a power of Prie≈øthood, fit only for the Pope and his Imps to put in practice.

But to ≈øay no more; in Charity I am bound to Compa≈ø≈øionate your Condition, which with all my Soul I do, and heartily can ≈øay to you, I am ≈øorry to ≈øee you in that mi≈øery; it was in your own power to have prevented it; but ≈øeeing you have made your ≈øelves Obnoxious to the Law, the only thing required of me, is to pronounce the Sentence that that Law hath Decreed. And therefore in the Name of the Court, I do pronounce this to be your Judgment.

sp.speaker: Mar≈øhall.
sp.p: May I ask one Que≈øtion, Mr. Recorder, before you pronounce Sentence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: No, Mr. Mar≈øhall, you can't ≈øpeak now; but this is your Judgment, and the Court does award it, That you the ≈øeveral Pri≈øoners now at the Bar, be conveyed from hence to the place from whence you came; and that you and every of you be conveyed from thence on Hurdles to the place of Execution, where every of you are to be ≈øeverally Hang'd by the Neck; That you be ≈øeverally cut down alive; That your Privy Members be cut off, your Bowels taken out and be burnt in your view; That your Heads be ≈øevered from your Bodies; That your Bodies be divided into four Quarters, which are to be di≈øpo≈øed at the Kings plea≈øure. And the God of infinite Mercy, have mercy upon your Souls.

div.p: Then the Pri≈øoners were carried away, and the Court Adjourned the Se≈ø≈øions.
